revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-01 00:48:26.000000000', 'message': "Remove some cruft from ratelimit tests

The tests were carefully setting up a mock for the 'http_connect'
function in the ratelimit module, but there is no such function
imported by the ratelimit module.

As far as I can tell, this has been the case since the ratelimit
middleware first appeared in 72d40bd (Mon Oct 4 14:11:48 2010 -0700).

Change-Id: If047184c6435aa1647050f50b499dc9feff4318d
"}]
commit_message:
Remove some cruft from ratelimit tests

The tests were carefully setting up a mock for the 'http_connect'
function in the ratelimit module, but there is no such function
imported by the ratelimit module.

As far as I can tell, this has been the case since the ratelimit
middleware first appeared in 72d40bd (Mon Oct 4 14:11:48 2010 -0700).

Change-Id: If047184c6435aa1647050f50b499dc9feff4318d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-01 10:42:38.000000000', 'message': "Use a venv with previous ansible version for upgrades

When doing the role upgrade, we run every playbook with current's
branch ansible. This is normal for the infrastructure bits (which
are running on current branch), but not for the installation of
the previous branch's role, which should use previous branch's
environment.

Depends-On: I7ebb045885dd645b820de2b7f75b46c755c015f6
Change-Id: I5fbf34688b8930d47cbb36866fe2436ce143ee00
Related-Bug: #1741471
"}]
commit_message:
Use a venv with previous ansible version for upgrades

When doing the role upgrade, we run every playbook with current's
branch ansible. This is normal for the infrastructure bits (which
are running on current branch), but not for the installation of
the previous branch's role, which should use previous branch's
environment.

Depends-On: I7ebb045885dd645b820de2b7f75b46c755c015f6
Change-Id: I5fbf34688b8930d47cbb36866fe2436ce143ee00
Related-Bug: #1741471

commit_message:
Update FAQ about updates of release notes

This updates the FAQ about how/when to update release notes.
In particular, it is now possible to update release notes for
intermediary releases that haven't yet been branched.

Change-Id: I90986e24d66ea9d183a255e0ac3b0f088e47c176

commit_message:
Remove unused code in common/neutron.py

This remove a line of code that is never executed, and if it were
to be executed, is incorrect, since the variable doesn't exist.

This is a follow up to 78e689e5390acf0d18b433c05495628012466c61.

Change-Id: Ic6085c8c070539ca383d0625a1c44ab9e31e1527

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ie9ccb527dd21145bce98a57f7ef6a2557cb3049c

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

commit_message:
IdP deletion triggers token revocation

- Ensure IdP deletion triggers token revocation
- Ensure IdP update triggers token revocation
- Added database migration script

Co-Authored-By: Marek Denis <marek.denis@cern.ch>

Change-Id: I2127cb8f2e6b8bfa70bc31dfe868166a6853c4c1
Closes-Bug: #1291157

[{'created': '2018-02-01 12:37:41.000000000', 'message': 'Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ida494299f8c159a73542982a9064c9092969b9d1
'}]
commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ida494299f8c159a73542982a9064c9092969b9d1

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Id3bfbf9ae2363aa8a9b559ed34910b7f673865b9

commit_message:
Add doc8 to pep8 check for glance_store project

This patch adds a doc8 check of .rst files to the current pep8 check.
It includes fixes to the .rst files that didn't pass the check.

Co-authored-By: Nguyen Van Trung <trungnv@vn.fujitsu.com>
Change-Id: If35a7a9ea64c7482306ef6403e9585b78da27fb9

commit_message:
Add support for configuring individual physical network MTUs

This is needed if a subset of your flat or VLAN provider networks have a MTU
that differ with what is set in global-physnet-mtu.

Change-Id: Ifd348311b5c313fa95d6ed49c32d9b26b0f5e662
Closes-Bug: #1663533

commit_message:
Restores sushy session functionality.

This patch restores sushy session functionality to the
SessionOrBasicAuth by moving can_refresh_session to its parent
SessionAuth. Also fixed verify being ignored.
Closes-Bug: 1744378

Change-Id: Ia9ce0fe965f13e2d7f7634957306fa4ce6746b39

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

commit_message:
Use a venv with previous ansible version for upgrades

When doing the role upgrade, we run every playbook with current's
branch ansible. This is normal for the infrastructure bits (which
are running on current branch), but not for the installation of
the previous branch's role, which should use previous branch's
environment.

Change-Id: I88e2616db193487905e1e1552695ec4847bcb4f9
Depends-On: I7ebb045885dd645b820de2b7f75b46c755c015f6
Related-Bug: #1741471

Kevin, 
https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_keystone/blob/stable/ocata/meta/main.yml#L43-L46 was how memcached was installed to localhost.

Now, https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_keystone/commit/ef9fc8f16355c49c79bf8c2cda070cfbc188f53a happened, due to many reasons, and no memcached is/should be installed to localhost.

I think we should wire this directive to our memcache servers, deployed in the memcached role/memcached playbook. So the old list of hosts was good, but wrongly formatted. I think the keystone role should get a list of memcached servers AND format it the way you want. So, in this case, it would be memcache_servers = ip1:port1,ip2:port2,... and the var would a list of hosts:ports.

The variable could still contain, in the role defaults [127.0.0.1:11211]. We'd only wire things up in the group vars, similar to all our existing wiring."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-01-16 11:09:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

jp,

"}, {'created': '2018-01-26 12:56:26.000000000', 'message': "Fix memcache caching w/ multiple cache servers

We found a bug recently where either oslo.cache or python-memcached
aren't using the `backend_argument` properly with more than one
memcached server defined. Until we get the memcached client libraries
figured out, `memcache_servers` works just the same for a single
memcached instance and it works defined with a ring of memcached
instances.

The current variable used for the directive memcache_servers was
pointing to localhost servers, that were historically used for
UUID token cache. Only the ``keystone_cache_backend_argument``
has the right list of servers, but the variable's content is
already formatted to match the cache_backend_argument directive,
and therefore needs editing to be used in ``memcache_servers``.

This is far too fragile, and simplification was needed. This
patch moves to a new variable (with a graceful deprecation
cycle), ``keystone_cache_servers``, a simple list containing the
servers.

The variable ``keystone_memcached_max_compare_and_set_retry``
wasn't used and was therefore removed too.

Related-Bug: 1743036
Closes-Bug: 1681695
Co-Authored-By: Lance Bragstad <lbragstad@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I85ebce8b41dd440e1866a08aa1329b3df798c04f

This is far too fragile, and simplification was needed. This
patch moves to a new variable (with a graceful deprecation
cycle), ``keystone_cache_servers``, a simple list containing the
servers.

The variable ``keystone_memcached_max_compare_and_set_retry``
wasn't used and was therefore removed too.

Related-Bug: 1743036
Closes-Bug: 1681695
Co-Authored-By: Lance Bragstad <lbragstad@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I85ebce8b41dd440e1866a08aa1329b3df798c04f
"}]
commit_message:
Fix memcache caching w/ multiple cache servers

We found a bug recently where either oslo.cache or python-memcached
aren't using the `backend_argument` properly with more than one
memcached server defined. Until we get the memcached client libraries
figured out, `memcache_servers` works just the same for a single
memcached instance and it works defined with a ring of memcached
instances.

The current variable used for the directive memcache_servers was
pointing to localhost servers, that were historically used for
UUID token cache. Only the ``keystone_cache_backend_argument``
has the right list of servers, but the variable's content is
already formatted to match the cache_backend_argument directive,
and therefore needs editing to be used in ``memcache_servers``.

This is far too fragile, and simplification was needed. This
patch moves to a new variable (with a graceful deprecation
cycle), ``keystone_cache_servers``, a simple list containing the
servers.

The variable ``keystone_memcached_max_compare_and_set_retry``
wasn't used and was therefore removed too.

Related-Bug: 1743036
Closes-Bug: 1681695
Co-Authored-By: Lance Bragstad <lbragstad@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I85ebce8b41dd440e1866a08aa1329b3df798c04f

commit_message:
Revert "final queens library releases"

Zuul mis-configuration caused the post jobs to fail before they were run.

This reverts commit b4bcf068b38753dc2036caeee69e396eeb5bede1.

Change-Id: I0c328477f01118bd22e0c0963d3892d374abec56
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add back support for the multiattach flag for volume create

As the 'multiattach' request parameter in volume create is
not formally deprecated out of the REST API via microversion,
we need to keep the functionality working.

Currently the 'multiattach' attribute on the volume is set by
the volume_type only, which means that we cannot create a
multi-attach volume the old way, the volume gets created with
'multiattach': false.

This patch fixes that.

Closes-Bug: #1745219

Change-Id: Iac67f112b0dc9353c6a66e6fbc81cc8324a2b37c

commit_message:
Remove helm_tests image key from openstack-exporter

The openstack-exporter doesn't have helm tests currently, so there
is no need for a helm_tests image key.

Change-Id: I7d1f737170a343e4ec66c4d7ace3ba76cdffb329

messages: [{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-02-01 15:10:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-02-01 15:11:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-02-01 15:17:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-01 15:10:11.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "add semaphore for publishing to the releases website"

Having a semaphore here broke zuul's ability to figure out what the job
should look like:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2018-February/000751.html

This reverts commit 2a9fea62abdbe58d5a9c24fbdbf246fbd6d5bb44.

Change-Id: I2196edc33aee03e9b2695b548b09790ed670e7f7
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "add semaphore for publishing to the releases website"

Having a semaphore here broke zuul's ability to figure out what the job
should look like:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2018-February/000751.html

This reverts commit 2a9fea62abdbe58d5a9c24fbdbf246fbd6d5bb44.

Change-Id: I2196edc33aee03e9b2695b548b09790ed670e7f7
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

Hi Yossi, thanks again. The ideia of turning the Health Manager into a singleton is good and works. But, the ideia is that I reuse the 'HealthHandler(object)' also on other Health Managers that might get created, for example on the CNI. So, I don't think this would work out. What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 27032, 'date': '2018-01-25 03:07:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 27032, 'date': '2018-01-26 03:04:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-01-30 07:57:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Add liveness checks to Kuryr Controller

This patch adds liveness checks for watcher and handlers, without passing the
manager's reference to modules that probably should not be aware of it.

Related-Bug: #1705429
Change-Id: I0192756c556b13f98302a57acedce269c278e260

commit_message:
Enable hacking-extensions H204, H205

This patch enable extensions:
-[H204] Use assert(Not)Equal to check for equality.
-[H205] Use assert(Greater|Less)(Equal) for comparison.

Change-Id: If1b09426deba024ce75ee0d2d687c2501a1e141d

[{'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2017-12-14 23:01:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2017-12-14 23:04:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Planning to add screenshots about creating bugs and blueprints to the Launchpad section. 

Also waiting for this[1] to merge so I can update the Storyboard URL rather than rewriting all of the content there to here.

Would love comments on what people think about this :) 
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/325474/'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2017-12-27 22:18:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9562, 'date': '2018-01-03 16:40:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(13 comments)

Hi Kendall,

Thanks for adding this new section. I added a few comments in line.

Beyond that please remove the trailing white spaces and the unnecessary tabs.

Also by opening the rendered version the images look too large. Not sure how much we need to cut back to have them fit well, maybe to 70% or maybe even to 50% to ensure the page reads well.

Finally it looks a bit odd that Launchpad has all the details on the page while StoryBoard is described elsewhere. Maybe we could move the Launchpad details to a sub-page here so the page is well balanced.

Thanks,
Ildikó'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2018-01-03 21:29:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2018-01-10 19:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(5 comments)

Thanks Kendall!'}, {'account_id': 15993, 'date': '2018-01-15 20:54:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

a few more catches, nothing major though'}, {'account_id': 9562, 'date': '2018-01-15 21:22:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Thanks Kendall!

I have a few additional suggestions besides the comments already in the patch. Otherwise looks good.

Thanks,
Ildikó'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2018-01-16 18:57:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2018-01-16 18:59:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(7 comments)

So I addressed all the comments except Ildiko's about a new section, I figured I would leave that up to discussion. I am open to it, but I don't think its necessary? Please share opinions :)

With regards to the dependent patch, I am working on getting that up to date and merged with the storyboard team so that this doesn't get held up."}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2018-01-17 23:59:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2018-01-18 16:33:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2018-01-18 17:20:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I really like the content Eric Fried did for this in the project team guide. Maybe it makes more sense for that content to be here for on-boarding?

https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/bugs.html'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-18 17:43:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

To be fair, I *only* ported the content from the wiki.'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2018-01-18 20:09:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2018-01-18 20:10:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)

I will do a follow up patch to add some of the info from the bug guide Eric did. I will also do a followup to update the stoyboard link when the storyboard gui manual gets updated/merged.'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2018-01-29 20:07:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

I'm good with this merging after being rebased."}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2018-01-30 20:04:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 9562, 'date': '2018-01-30 20:58:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

I'm ok with a follow-up too. Thanks kendall!"}]

[{'created': '2018-02-01 10:46:15.000000000', 'message': "Use a venv with previous ansible version for upgrades

When doing the role upgrade, we run every playbook with current's
branch ansible. This is normal for the infrastructure bits (which
are running on current branch), but not for the installation of

commit_message:
Use a venv with previous ansible version for upgrades

When doing the role upgrade, we run every playbook with current's
branch ansible. This is normal for the infrastructure bits (which
are running on current branch), but not for the installation of
the previous branch's role, which should use previous branch's
environment.

Depends-On: I7ebb045885dd645b820de2b7f75b46c755c015f6
Change-Id: I7069c906395b37e8af20db82d88d8a069faf5f79

commit_message:
Use a venv with previous ansible version for upgrades

When doing the role upgrade, we run every playbook with current's
branch ansible. This is normal for the infrastructure bits (which
are running on current branch), but not for the installation of
the previous branch's role, which should use previous branch's
environment.

Depends-On: I7ebb045885dd645b820de2b7f75b46c755c015f6
Change-Id: Ied3168a4a2df385f8cba8f89b2efab208e639e55
Related-Bug: #1741471

registering as ready before timing out. This rolls the version back
until those issues are addressed

commit_message:
Use a venv with previous ansible version for upgrades

When doing the role upgrade, we run every playbook with current's
branch ansible. This is normal for the infrastructure bits (which
are running on current branch), but not for the installation of
the previous branch's role, which should use previous branch's
environment.

This patch also renames test-upgrade-pre to test-upgrade, to
be in line with other roles.

Depends-On: I7ebb045885dd645b820de2b7f75b46c755c015f6
Change-Id: I3e7198d368ef1d7373bb036f60a75d1ddfa4b45c
Related-Bug: #1741471

commit_message:
Create a default share type

Tempest assumes a default share type already created
to work. This means, if a default share type is not
created and not specified in the conf file, tempest
tests fail. A workaround is to create the default share
type as part of the environment setup for all the tests
that need it. This patch set does that.

Change-Id: I3efbeef477ddefa715a6a36ec9ca49aca15200ba
Closes-Bug: #1743472

commit_message:
Tie keystone admin API port to what we configure in t-h-t

This only exposes the port that we actually will use for the admin API
port, as well as bonding the actual port to what we configure of the
keystone service (apache and the keystone configuration).

Change-Id: I4b27d774d5ab291340c0a3e537efbb75ed311d49
Closes-Bug: #1746180

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I365e80d0ae59171811680c9f608f409cebf878ef
'}]
commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I365e80d0ae59171811680c9f608f409cebf878ef

  If the user deploys an environment with
  neutron-l2gw-opendaylight.yaml, it won't have L3 networking
  and trunk ports.

Change-Id: Idf2222a99203787f2295a0991ef8f392bdeb87e6
Signed-off-by: Ricardo Noriega <rnoriega@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 4260db4bce9224137df6d722af5884139274db08)
"}]
commit_message:
Default service plugin for OpenDaylight scenario are not present

  If the user deploys an environment with
  neutron-l2gw-opendaylight.yaml, it won't have L3 networking
  and trunk ports.

Change-Id: Idf2222a99203787f2295a0991ef8f392bdeb87e6
Signed-off-by: Ricardo Noriega <rnoriega@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 4260db4bce9224137df6d722af5884139274db08)

commit_message:
Improve multiattach error message

With multi-attach on the way, the current message when you try to attach
a non-multiattach enabled disk is less than perfect. If you've forgotten
to set multiattach on volume create, you will get this error when you
try to attach it to the second instance:

"volume is already attached"

This updates the error message to make it clearer.

Closes-Bug: 1741943

Change-Id: I7110cb87388ec8d39aa8b604208a161e890f3ab2

commit_message:
Merge Connection and OpenStackCloud

There's no good reason to have the shade functions in a cloud attribute.
Go ahead and dive all the way in and make OpenStackCloud a mixin class.

There was one wrapped exception that got removed and thus the test to test
that we were wrapping it.

Change-Id: Iebd80fe5bc511ea879ea71aa88ce7d79c5e8fa58

commit_message:
Add OpenStackCloud object to Connection

Make a cloud attribute on Connection so that people with a Connection
can also use shade features.

This changes the default for shade's list_flavors to NOT fetching
extra_specs, which is very much yay.

Change-Id: I45a5f7f11a9c5ab3c77443a8f5df26089243334c

commit_message:
Ensure Connection can be made from keyword arguments

Although driving configuration from clouds.yaml and environment
variables is super handy for many use cases, there are also plenty where
avoiding config files or environment variables is important.

Add a flag, "load_envvars" which defaults to True but can be disabled.

Update the Connection constructor to set load_yaml_config and
load_envvars to False if a named cloud is not given.

Update the docs to make it clear which form should be used for which use
case. Also, move the profile backwards compat documentation to its own
document so that it doesn't present needless complexity to users.

Change-Id: I6e05da5e73aff4143550e1d18fb0f743d51f2b70

subject: Add a descriptor object for each service proxy
messages: [{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-01-30 15:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-01-30 18:20:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-01-31 02:13:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 3099, 'date': '2018-01-31 22:37:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-02-01 11:52:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:\n\nrecheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-30 15:03:03.000000000', 'message': 'Add a descriptor object for each service proxy

The end-goal here is to be able to do version discovery rather than
relying on config and in-code version defaults for what gets attached to
the connection as the service proxy for a service. However, since we're
currently constructing Adapter objects at instantation time we'd have to
authenticate AND do version discovery on every service when we create a
Connection to be able to do that.

That would be bad.

Add a Descriptor class that creates the Proxy object on-demand. That is,
when someone does "conn.compute", a Proxy will be created and returned.

To support doing that without a ton of duplicate copy-pasta for each
service, add a metaclass to Connection which reads os-service-types and
does the import lookup / BaseProxy fallback as part of Connection class
creation. One of the upsides to this is that we can add docstrings to
the service descriptor objects - meaning that the docs for Connection
actually list the proxy objects.

While we're in here, fix a NOTE in a connection doc string and add a
reference to BaseProxy in the docs so that it'll show up in the docs
too.

Change-Id: I3bef5de60b848146fc8563d853774769d0875c65

commit_message:
Add a descriptor object for each service proxy

The end-goal here is to be able to do version discovery rather than
relying on config and in-code version defaults for what gets attached to
the connection as the service proxy for a service. However, since we're
currently constructing Adapter objects at instantation time we'd have to
authenticate AND do version discovery on every service when we create a
Connection to be able to do that.

That would be bad.

Add a Descriptor class that creates the Proxy object on-demand. That is,
when someone does "conn.compute", a Proxy will be created and returned.

To support doing that without a ton of duplicate copy-pasta for each
service, add a metaclass to Connection which reads os-service-types and
does the import lookup / BaseProxy fallback as part of Connection class
creation. One of the upsides to this is that we can add docstrings to
the service descriptor objects - meaning that the docs for Connection
actually list the proxy objects.

While we're in here, fix a NOTE in a connection doc string and add a
reference to BaseProxy in the docs so that it'll show up in the docs
too.

Change-Id: I3bef5de60b848146fc8563d853774769d0875c65

subject: Install SELinux packages asynchronously
messages:
[{'account_id': 538, 'date': '2018-01-31 23:08:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-01-31 23:13:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Interesting. I'd like to see the results."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-02-01 10:09:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

I'm not a huge fan of using async as the tasks can never be retried on failure, which means the task is more likely to fail in bad connectivity environments. However, given that this is isolated to CentOS I guess I can go along with it."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-01 14:14:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-31 23:08:19.000000000', 'message': 'Install SELinux packages asynchronously

This patch moves the SELinux packages into their own variable
and installs them via async. This ensures that the LXC packages
install faster.

Closes-Bug: 1746617
Change-Id: Ic05e2fcd5c80bd0b2c4b86832bcf715a28ac8f80
'}]
commit_message:
Install SELinux packages asynchronously

This patch moves the SELinux packages into their own variable
and installs them via async. This ensures that the LXC packages
install faster.

Closes-Bug: 1746617
Change-Id: Ic05e2fcd5c80bd0b2c4b86832bcf715a28ac8f80

subject: Fix Galera socket for RedHat
messages: [{'account_id': 13095, 'date': '2018-01-31 17:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-01-31 17:12:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 27281, 'date': '2018-01-31 18:19:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1\n\nThis fixed my issue reported in https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1746547'}, {'account_id': 538, 'date': '2018-02-01 13:38:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-31 17:02:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Galera socket for RedHat

At the moment, RedHat currently installs and listens on the
/var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock path, this can be seen by the following:

mysqld  13627 mysql   33u     unix 0xffff88079261cc00        0t0   3312115 /var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock

This patch resolves it which will allow the health checks to
function as they rely on the [client] section which contains
an incorrect path.

Change-Id: Iec88e911c6cf207bcea5bd067f9743b3eb50f60e
(cherry picked from commit f2bfbd38513ac8d61ba4e02a4d5ef6cbbca259cc)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Galera socket for RedHat

At the moment, RedHat currently installs and listens on the
/var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock path, this can be seen by the following:

mysqld  13627 mysql   33u     unix 0xffff88079261cc00        0t0   3312115 /var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock

This patch resolves it which will allow the health checks to
function as they rely on the [client] section which contains
an incorrect path.

Change-Id: Iec88e911c6cf207bcea5bd067f9743b3eb50f60e
(cherry picked from commit f2bfbd38513ac8d61ba4e02a4d5ef6cbbca259cc)

commit_message:
Support admin to get all events

Currently admin can only get project_id consistent events, while
sometimes admin need to get all the events, so add a parameter
"all_tenants" for the api to achieve this purpose.

Change-Id: I7c479a63c41d4b0fbf645bdb1b70f0259b0cb859
(cherry picked from commit f7d5e0564a3eb807146730c8bcdc0777f38b1147)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-01 12:56:10.000000000', 'message': 'Add server-side names to query param checking

Rework the query params checking to include server-side names,
as well as move to dedicated function on QueryParameters.

Change transpose logic to include server-side names as fallback,
with precedence for client-side names.

Add tests for these changes, and fix missing assertEqual in old
query mapping test.

Change-Id: I3705075a0ea2911a06619a6e4dd13233c725887e
Closes-bug: #1746535
'}]
commit_message:
Add server-side names to query param checking

Rework the query params checking to include server-side names,
as well as move to dedicated function on QueryParameters.

Change transpose logic to include server-side names as fallback,
with precedence for client-side names.

Add tests for these changes, and fix missing assertEqual in old
query mapping test.

Change-Id: I3705075a0ea2911a06619a6e4dd13233c725887e
Closes-bug: #1746535

The widget ngTags is used to select dimensions. This widget does not
work with IE 11 and the AngularJS versions provided by Horizon. Replacing
ng-click event with ng-mousedown event, because the ng-click event does
not fire on IE11 in the given dialog layout.

commit_message:
Fixing 'Create Alarm Definition' for IE11

The widget ngTags is used to select dimensions. This widget does not
work with IE 11 and the AngularJS versions provided by Horizon. Replacing
ng-click event with ng-mousedown event, because the ng-click event does
not fire on IE11 in the given dialog layout.

Change-Id: I9918debd164dce7ddc4bba15a07d6f3edddc7a09
Story: 2001504
Task: 6295
(cherry picked from commit 4c2cabb50b0b39621d0dda74f2ffb5120f825c1d)
(cherry picked from commit cdaf5b36c94faf958d2c6da4d551cf8ae63012a7)

commit_message:
Add footer to Validation Details modal

The Validation Details modal was missing a footer which
includes the "Close" button. This will allow it to be
consistent with other modals of this type.

Change-Id: I4eb63f38f4580dc5ce5ed1c1ed5f2181ea559f0f

commit_message:
Fix SELinux file contexts for nova's ssh keys

The original SELinux file context equivalance that was added for
/var/lib/nova was too broad and needs to be made more specific.

This patch removes the old equivalence record and replaces it with
a specific file context rule. This allows live migrations to work
with CentOS 7 systems that have SELinux in enforcing mode.

Closes-Bug: 1742732
Depends-On: I52901ac48f9a95d0fe6b010f5940b5c39fce1aba
Change-Id: I8f7c750edc1c7b354343f07230eb17d1357001de

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-31 22:53:26.000000000', 'message': 'Add server-side names to query param checking

Rework the query params checking to include server-side names,
as well as move to dedicated function on QueryParameters.

Change transpose logic to include server-side names as fallback,
with precedence for client-side names.

Add tests for these changes, and fix missing assertEqual in old
query mapping test.

Change-Id: I3705075a0ea2911a06619a6e4dd13233c725887e
Closes-bug: #1746535
'}]
commit_message:
Add server-side names to query param checking

Rework the query params checking to include server-side names,
as well as move to dedicated function on QueryParameters.

Change transpose logic to include server-side names as fallback,
with precedence for client-side names.

Add tests for these changes, and fix missing assertEqual in old
query mapping test.

Change-Id: I3705075a0ea2911a06619a6e4dd13233c725887e
Closes-bug: #1746535

commit_message:
Fix TypeError for overrided get methods

Get methods fixed in this commit would be called from
openstack.proxy._get where an error_message parameter will be passed.
TypeError will be raised if the keyword argument 'error_message' is
missing.

Change-Id: I2fdfb5c1cdf9e2e58669b44d6e8b5f2d118b3d63
Closes-Bug: #1743891

commit_message:
Add user agent for haproxy health checks

This patch adds a user agent string to HTTP health checks performed
by haproxy. This allows a deployer to easily filter out these
requests via uwsgi routes (or other means) and avoid filling up
their logs.

Partial-Bug: 1742718
Change-Id: Ifb95cabfb104753a5085a65479d5b6137e5dbc03

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I995154c056dd99b3a2c0ee9f7ddd9077e5686b79

Marking WIP'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-09-04 23:56:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#automated-testing

- gate-swift-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-docs-ubuntu-xenial/0e9dc44//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 47s
- gate-swift-pep8-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-pep8-ubuntu-xenial/b7a1913/ : FAILURE in 2m 18s
- gate-swift-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-python27-ubuntu-xenial/09d924c/ : FAILURE in 5m 53s
- gate-swift-python34 http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-python34/1791919/ : SUCCESS in 1m 49s
- gate-swift-python35-nv http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-python35-nv/3c324de/ : SUCCESS in 1m 47s (non-voting)
- gate-swift-tox-func-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-tox-func-ubuntu-xenial/5e5ca2f/ : SUCCESS in 3m 31s
- gate-swift-tox-func-in-process-fast-post-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-tox-func-in-process-fast-post-ubuntu-xenial/05a6c9a/ : SUCCESS in 4m 58s
- gate-swift-tox-func-in-process-encryption-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-tox-func-in-process-encryption-ubuntu-xenial/5ad2c8a/ : SUCCESS in 3m 16s (non-voting)
- gate-tempest-dsvm-full-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-full-ubuntu-xenial/5d4ead7/ : SUCCESS in 59m 20s
- gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-identity-v3-only-full-nv http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-identity-v3-only-full-nv/36c4f42/ : FAILURE in 20m 00s (non-voting)
- gate-grenade-dsvm-ubuntu-trusty http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-grenade-dsvm-ubuntu-trusty/3c833bf/ : SUCCESS in 38m 21s
- gate-swift-dsvm-functional http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-dsvm-functional/64dba1b/ : SUCCESS in 26m 28s
- gate-swift-tox-bandit-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-tox-bandit-ubuntu-xenial/c57d1bc/ : SUCCESS in 2m 45s (non-voting)
- gate-swift-dsvm-functional-identity-v3-only-nv http://logs.openstack.org/71/365371/1/check/gate-swift-dsvm-functional-identity-v3-only-nv/ffe4314/ : SUCCESS in 27m 08s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2016-09-07 23:58:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think rather than model this off of SLO's as an independent middleware I'd be interested to see it more closely modeled off bulk upload (which AIUI has a per-request based API rather than manifest API).

I see this as having a lot of potential for clients that don't want to manage their own concurrency.

Have lots of objects but want big fat single stream throughput and don't want to spin up 100's of workers - just tar it before you upload and the swift proxy will do all the hard concurrency work!

Have a bunch of tiny objects in swift [1] that you need on your disks right now but don't want to spin up 100's of workers - just download them all as one big tarball and the swift proxy will do all the hard concurrency work!

I think it'd feel weird a half organized if we don't update bulk upload to create TLO - but in the upload use-case I'm not sure if there's much of a need to create the TLO manifest unless you specifically know you want to download exactly that set of objects together all the time?

I see a lot more use cases for dynamism here:

"download all of the objects in container xyz with prefix abc"

I'm struggling with a use-case that is truly bi-modal - "sometimes I want to download a specific tarball with all of it's specific contents - sometimes I want to download specific pieces in that specific tarball" - is that a thing?  How do you even know what's *in* the TLO manifest?

Joel,

In your experience are people pre-seeding these TLO's or is it very much "do the listing, make the TLO, download the TLO" sort of workflow?  If the former, can you elaborate on the use-case?

-Clay

1. maybe hey were bulk uploaded?  :P'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2016-09-08 00:52:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Being able to download things as tarballs would be pretty handy.

I'm going to think out loud here, so this might be full of bad ideas.

I wonder if there's a way to do this with SLOs instead of a whole new middleware. Looking at the TLO creation, it seems like most of the new stuff (relative to SLO) is in the storage of tar headers. What if, hypothetically, we made this work in a streaming fashion on download from a normal SLO manifest? It'd have to be a chunked download since we wouldn't know the content length beforehand (since tar header sizes vary depending on the object name), but it might be possible to do without a data format change.

We could add stuff to the listing iter that SegmentedIterable consumes, like a preamble and postamble. Then TLO could put tar headers in the preamble and end-of-archive in the last postamble. That'll get the listing iter up to a 7-tuple from its current 5-tuple, so it's probably time to just convert it to a dictionary. That'll make default values easier (like "" for preamble and postamble).

If you made it a mode of SLO, that'd save you lots of duplicated functionality (the bulk delete, the upload validation, the rate limiting...) and let you do this with a pretty small amount of added code.

Thinking more about the content length, if we hit a "simple" manifest (no submanifests), then we could have a Content-Length header in that case. It's only when there's submanifests that we can't immediately compute the tar headers for everything based on the one manifest; we'd have to do more (potentially a whole lot more) IO in order to figure it out.

I'm not sure what the UI for this would look like. Query param on download, like download-format=tar? Maybe a new thing on manifest creation, something like multipart-manifest=tar, then store that and do the right thing at download? I think the second one's a bit nicer... I can't imagine when you'd want to sometimes download a tarball of files A to Z, and sometimes download the concatenation of files A to Z, and I think it'll just confuse users when they get the wrong one and their download is full of garbage.

(I may be a little biased because I have a use case for SegmentedIterable with preamble/postamble in some as-yet-unreleased code, but I can't justify modifying Swift upstream for my own convenience. However, if this change *just happens* to make my life easier... ;) )'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2016-09-08 01:00:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Wait, I'm dumb. If we're doing this at upload time, then of course we can compute the sum of the tar-header sizes and stick that in sysmeta. Then when we see a submanifest during creation, we can store that sum in our manifest, so we should always be able to have a content length."}, {'account_id': 9216, 'date': '2016-09-09 15:14:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the detailed comments guys, I really appreciate the feedback.

Clay: I understand your desire to have this as a more dynamic request and I agree that this would be a nice feature to have. However, although I can see use cases for both approaches, my immediate use case requires something modelled more closely on SLO than bulk upload. In particular I want to be able to (1) guarantee that changed files invalidate the tarball, and (2) be able to combine this with tempURL to allow downloads of sets of data in a defined structure without the downloader having any auth access to the storage account. Having said that, I think there's a lot of value in the dynamic version too so I'll look into the possibility of a separate patch to add a dynamic version. Let's face it, this is the DLO vs SLO battle all over again...

Sam: I was prepared for the 'make this an extension of SLO' comment and I will work towards that with the next version. The only reasons I didn't take that approach to begin with is that (1) I initially imagined making this available as a separate middleware and (2) Having a separate middleware was easier to deploy internally than maintaining a fork of SLO :S

Looks like I've got some work to do before Barcelona!"}, {'account_id': 9216, 'date': '2016-10-20 11:14:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-20 12:03:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

(4 comments)

I am still making my way through this.  A lot of good work to go over :-).  But ... have some feedback to begin with.

There are new lines written in request_helpers that do not get covered by unit tests from test_request_helpers or from test_slo.  Lines 470, 478, 486, 515, 524, 672, 693-696, 703, 714.  If some cases are sanity checks only, that is ok.  But I think that some of them are reasonable candidates for unit tests.

In addition to the below comments for docs in the mw itself, add docs to doc/source/api/large_objects.rst'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2016-12-27 20:28:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

(16 comments)

Still need to get through the meat of the change to SegmentedIterable, but at the very least we need to be better about input validation so we don't hit TypeErrors while decoding.

This all got me thinking about data URIs. I wonder if it would make sense to define a new type of segment rather than adding more options to the existing segment type. Instead of having something like

[
 {"path": "c/o/1",
  "preamble": "preamble1",
  "postamble": "postamble1"},
 {"path": "c/o/2",
  "preamble": "preamble2",
  "postamble": "postamble2"}
]

we could have something like

[
 {"data": "preamble1"},
 {"path": "c/o/1"},
 {"data": "postamble1preamble2"},
 {"path": "c/o/2"},
 {"data": "postamble2"}
]

and maybe double the number of allowed segments. (Now that we do concurrent HEADs, this seems like a not-crazy proposition.) A segment dict should then either have

* a "path" key (and any, all, or none of the existing optional keys) or
* a "data" key and nothing else.'}, {'account_id': 9216, 'date': '2017-01-13 23:34:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 9216, 'date': '2017-01-13 23:35:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

(17 comments)

Okay, I've covered all these comments."}, {'account_id': 9216, 'date': '2017-01-13 23:38:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

I've covered most of the direct comments on v13.

I still need to work out how to improve the coverage on the request_helpers, but it seems like SLO/DLO can't reach some of that code and they are the only consumer of the SegmentedIterable.

I will add docs to doc/source/api/large_objects.rst and look into the coverage when I'm back from vacation on Jan 25th."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-01-14 00:36:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Verified+1

(3 comments)

Input validation is looking better and better.

If anyone wants to test where this is going, I threw together https://gist.github.com/tipabu/5c96175d26fac1ec1771b5d01c6573a7 (based on https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tar_(computing)#Header) to help write SLO manifests that result in tar files.

This generally seems to make sense (at least, after applying http://paste.openstack.org/show/607419/ -- I think I'd be +1 with that) but I'm pretty sure I need to take a closer look at the changes to request_helpers.py -- even after breaking out _time_limit_iter, _pre_post_amble_iter (which is basically what _internal_iter *used to be*) is a bit unwieldy :-/

The good news is, I've been able to create an SLO that has tar headers & padding coming from pre/postambles!"}, {'account_id': 9216, 'date': '2017-04-21 16:12:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

(2 comments)

Cheers for the review, I'll have a dig into the decoding pre/post on download (thanks for the diff).

Just one thing though, if you're going to make tars you might be better off using Python's tarfile module: https://gist.github.com/joel-wright/b8282f689ff1a622c035cd2741e8e265 - As soon as this is accepted I'm going to be finishing off a separate middleware to make tar SLOs without the user having to calculate the tar headers/padding.
the user having to do it manually.

I'll spend some time on this over the weekend and push a new version."}, {'account_id': 9216, 'date': '2017-04-25 16:09:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-25 17:36:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Verified-1

Hi Christian, I do have a (currently very broken) TLO implementation based off a much older version of this code. I was planning to resurrect it as soon as we got some agreement on the API for adding data into the SLO manifest. Clay/Tim have suggested some form of data-segment rather than attaching a pre/postamble to real segments, so it would be good to  talk through this. Let me know what you think.'}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2017-06-13 07:47:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Code-Review+1

(4 comments)

Nice work Joel, well done!

I used Tims gist (https://gist.github.com/tipabu/5c96175d26fac1ec1771b5d01c6573a7) for testing this, and it worked as expected:

 python tartest.py > manifest.tar
 dd if=/dev/zero of=__end_tar bs=1 count=512
 swift upload c tox.ini --object-name o
 swift upload c setup.cfg --object-name o2
 swift upload c __end_tar

 curl -i "http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1/AUTH_test/c/manifest.tar?multipart-manifest=put" -X PUT -H "x-object-meta-mtime: 1497337444.222708" -H "Content-Length: 1995" -H "Content-Type: " -H "X-Auth-Token: AUTH_tk78b1bfe932e049258fc097486baf44e8" --data-binary @manifest.tar

Then downloaded the manifest.tar and voilá:

 swift download c manifest.tar
 tar tvf manifest.tar
 > -rw-r----- 0/0            4396 1970-01-01 00:00 setup.cfg
 > -rw-r----- 0/0            3935 1970-01-01 00:00 tox.ini

I left a few comments inline. Looks already quite good, nice test coverage and I don't have any big concerns right now, but I want to do some more testing - thus only a +1 for now.

Despite increasing the max manifest size to 8MiB, this will be somewhat limited to ~ 8000 files per tarfile, pre-/postamble adds around 1kiB per file to the manifest. This should be probably mentioned in the docstring as well?'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2017-06-21 21:23:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

Here's some thoughts of mine:

I like the use of preambles and postambles instead of explicit data segments. That way, just like a SLO is restricted to N segments, a tarball is restricted to N files. That's easier to think about, and simpler for end users.

The other upside to pre/postambles is that it precludes making literal-data-only SLOs. Yes, if users want to store their data base64-encoded with a bunch of JSON crud around it and pay for the privilege, that's not going to really break anything, but it's a dumb thing to do and we shouldn't allow it IMO :)

Looking a bit more at the code, there's a couple spots I'd change. I'd prefer it if SLO were to base64-decode the pre/postambles prior to passing them into SegmentedIterable. SegmentedIterable is more about fetching bytes and jamming them together; SLO is the one who enforces base64 format and knows about JSON and such.

The ETag computation looks good. 

The ratelimiting stuff looks good. I don't think it's important whether or not the pre/postambles count towards a segment being small or not, so let me go on the record as saying that this way is fine, but if you want to do the other way, that's fine too.

The spot where I start to struggle is in SegmentedIterable's code. Between _pre_post_amble_iter and _coalescing_iter, I start to get lost. I'm not saying any of it's wrong, just that it gets confusing. Maybe toss some comments at the top of those guys with examples of what they yield? I'll stare at it a little further and see if it comes into focus."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2017-08-23 22:57:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26:

Just to play Devil's advocate for the data segments -- we've already seen object-backed segments need to grow extensions like range support. With a separate segment type, we can keep whatever extensions we may want for encoding-data-in-the-manifest isolated. Two that come to mind:

- "encoding"

> base64 is nice, but what if I want hex to make it easier for humans to read individual bytes? Or, since it's already Unicode anyway, we could add support for something like https://github.com/qntm/base65536
> 
> Alternatively, you could specify something like UTF-8 so the proxy knows how to translate the Unicode to bytes-on-the-wire. This could be particularly handy when the wrapping data is textual, like if you're building XML large documents.

- "repeat"

> More immediately useful to TLO, we could do ad-hoc run-length encoding. It seems silly that the last segment will have a postamble that includes 1300 bytes worth of "AAAA....AAAA==" -- why not something like

 {"data": "AA==", "repeat": 1024}

These are still hypotheticals, though; I'm still not sure which way would ultimately be better... but this *does* have the advantage of having already been written, which is not insignificant.

(Sorry in advance for the formatting -- I have no idea how to make gerrit do <dl>s. Hopefully this will look not-too-terrible?)'}, {'account_id': 9216, 'date': '2017-08-29 22:05:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 27.'}, {'account_id': 9216, 'date': '2017-08-29 22:17:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 27:

Thanks for the comments Sam.

I've added some comments to the iterators within SegmentedIterable to try to make the situation more clear. All that's really going on there is an attempt to separate concerns. The iterator methods are just wrappers around each other with each one attempting to focus on a single task:

    _internal_iter(_time_limit_iter(_pre_post_amble_iter(_coalescing_iter(response.app_iter))))

For your comment about base64.decode() in the data before passing it to SegmentedIterable, I believe that's exactly what is going on. The pre/postambles are decoded in SloGetContext.get_or_head_response() before being passed to SegmentedIterable.

Hopefully the extra comments in SegmentedIterable will make things a bit more clear.

I need to have more time to think about Tim's suggestions!"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-08-29 23:35:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Verified+1

If we can clean it up more later, so much the better, but I think it's in a reasonable state as-is."}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-01-30 10:49:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Looking great. I've been playing with recursive depth and manifests with slo segments and data segments.

If I have a data segment before a sub slo, once it reaches recursive depth it returns 200 but on the commandline it freezes (or stuck waiting for a timeout I never waited for). In the recursive test it doesn't log the recursive error (freeze?), here's a patch to recreate: http://paste.openstack.org/show/657970/

Test output:

======================================================================
FAIL: test_recursion_limit (test.unit.common.middleware.test_slo.TestSloGetManifest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/home/vagrant/swift/test/unit/common/middleware/test_slo.py", line 2720, in 
test_recursion_limit
    "While processing manifest '/v1/AUTH_test/gettest/man1', "
AssertionError: Lists differ: [] != ["While processing manifest '/...

Second list contains 1 additional elements.
First extra element 0:
While processing manifest '/v1/AUTH_test/gettest/man1', max recursion depth was exceeded

- []
+ ["While processing manifest '/v1/AUTH_test/gettest/man1', max recursion depth was exceeded"]
    """Fail immediately, with the given message."""
>>  raise self.failureException('Lists differ: [] != ["While processing manifest \'/...\n\nSecond list contains 1 additional elements.\nFirst extra element 0:\nWhile processing manifest \'/v1/AUTH_test/gettest/man1\', max recursion depth was exceeded\n\n- []\n+ ["While processing manifest \'/v1/AUTH_test/gettest/man1\', max recursion depth was exceeded"]')
----------------------------------------------------------------------

On the command line, freezing:

  vagrant@server1:~/swift$ curl -i -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" $STORAGE_URL/c/slo11
  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Length: 1816
  Accept-Ranges: bytes
  Last-Modified: Tue, 30 Jan 2018 10:03:39 GMT
  Etag: "5c7f8ee4c5d7f821f6dcdd5279ff42f2"
  X-Timestamp: 1517306618.21261
  X-Static-Large-Object: True
  Content-Type: application/octet-stream
  X-Trans-Id: txaa3a4903842b4b94ae129-005a704b7c
  X-Openstack-Request-Id: txaa3a4903842b4b94ae129-005a704b7c
  Date: Tue, 30 Jan 2018 10:39:56 GMT


  <freeze or waiting for some timeout>

Of course it's the last thing I was about to check, and it's getting late here, so haven't had time to look into it at all yet. But thought I'd comment my current findings. Will delve into it more in the morning. (hopefully its something I've done wrong).

If it is me, I'll find out in the morning when I delve in.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-30 19:38:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 42:

(2 comments)

Interesting; it works on my machine.

Here's the test script I'm using: https://gist.github.com/smerritt/d5d3ca419a1007c365e29a1fb73a4b4b"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-30 20:40:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 42:

I'm pretty sure it's to do with the fact that Matt's diff no longer consumes the body -- as a result, we never load up the sub manifests, and never find out that the recursion depth is exceeded. Still a little curious that including the assertion on body gets us to fail with

 '' != 'body01body02body03body04body05body06body07body08body09body10'

What happened to body06 through body10?"}, {'account_id': 26946, 'date': '2018-01-30 21:20:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 42:

I've been following these comments coming in, but I'm ski guiding this week so I won't get a chance to investigate until next week. I'll have a proper look as soon as I can when I get back home."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-30 21:42:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-30 22:04:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 42: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Barring the one unit test that Matt pointed out, I'm pretty much happy with this."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-31 02:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 43.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-31 02:15:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 43: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

Still good. I'm "meh" on whether the test needed updating, but w/e.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-01-31 09:10:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 43: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Cool, thanks for updating the test. And Tim for explaining the Curl issue. If I add the --no-buffer or timeout it works as expected.

Code looks good, mechanics works. I like the slight SLO api (manifest) change to allow us to inline some data segments. Base64 so we can keep binary as text.

An I've tested it a bunch on my SAIO (sorry again). I think it's good. Even Sam is happy with it. Lets get it in."}, {'account_id': 26946, 'date': '2018-01-31 12:22:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 43:

That's awesome! My first proper Swift patch merged!"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-31 19:13:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 43: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-31 22:18:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 43:

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-09-04 22:56:59.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add Tar Large Object Middleware

This patch adds a new middleware based on SLO that allows a
user to create a new object that represents a tarball containing
a given list of objects. Tarballs with >1000 objects can be created
by adding sub_tlos. In order to create the tarball, no information
is required beyond the object names, however some extra information
can be supplied for checking purposes.

This patch is expected to start a discussion, and some things will
need investigation (e.g. the etag of a tlo is currently the md5sum
of the concantenated etags of the objects it contains ignoring
tar header and footer information).

The patch also includes a number of TODO items (it was developed
against swift 2.2.x and the tests are currently incomplete).

Change-Id: Ib8dc216a84d370e6da7d6b819af79582b671d699
'}, {'created': '2016-10-20 11:14:10.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add Preamble and Postamble to SLO and SegmentedIterable

This patch updates the SLO middleware and SegmentedIterable to add
support for user specified preamble and postamble data for each
segment. If specified the preamble/postamble data are expected to
be base64 encoded data to be added before/after an object segment
within an SLO.

This patch is a prerequisite for future patches enabling static
and dynamic downloads of large objects as tarballs. A link to the
T(S/D)LO patch will be added later.

This patch is expected to start a discussion, and some things will
need investigation (e.g. the etag of an SLO is currently the md5sum
of the concantenated etags of the objects it contains ignoring
the preamble and postamble information).

The patch also includes a number of TODO items (it was originally
developed against swift 2.2.x and the tests are currently
incomplete).

Change-Id: Ib8dc216a84d370e6da7d6b819af79582b671d699
'}, {'created': '2016-10-31 18:49:26.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add Preamble and Postamble to SLO and SegmentedIterable

segment. If specified the preamble/postamble data are expected to

within an SLO.

download of large objects as tarballs. The TLO patch will be added
as a dependent patch later.

commit_message:
Add support for data segments to SLO and SegmentedIterable

This patch updates the SLO middleware and SegmentedIterable to add
support for user-specified inlined-data segments. Such segments will
contain base64-encoded data to be added before/after an object-backed
segment within an SLO. To accommodate the potential extra data we
increase the default SLO maximum manifest size from 2MiB to 8MiB.
The default maximum number of segments remains 1000, but this will
only be enforced for object-backed segments.

This patch is a prerequisite for a future patch enabling the
download of large objects as tarballs. The TLO patch will be added
as a dependent patch later.

UpgradeImpact
=============
During a rolling upgrade, an updated proxy may write a manifest that
out-of-date proxies will not be able to read. This will resolve itself
once the upgrade completes on all nodes.

Change-Id: Ib8dc216a84d370e6da7d6b819af79582b671d699

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

commit_message:
Fixing 'Create Alarm Definition' for IE11

The widget ngTags is used to select dimensions. This widget does not
work with IE 11 and the AngularJS versions provided by Horizon. Replacing
ng-click event with ng-mousedown event, because the ng-click event does
not fire on IE11 in the given dialog layout.

Change-Id: I9918debd164dce7ddc4bba15a07d6f3edddc7a09
Story: 2001504
Task: 6295
(cherry picked from commit 4c2cabb50b0b39621d0dda74f2ffb5120f825c1d)

commit_message:
Update Custom Profile field help/error messages

This contribution updates the inline help message as well as the
error message for the Custom Profile field to be more user friendly.
This field can be seen when the user chooses to tag a node with a
"Custom Profile".

Change-Id: I2a88a4fc5f58c7d61e981f1db2130e07e8054310
Closes-Bug: #1673526

commit_message:
Adds documentation

This patch adds basic details about:

* Supported OS versions
* Requirements and host configurations
* MSI installer, its features, and arguments
* Further steps after installing and configuring the
  nova-compute service
* Troubleshooting tips
* Usage

Change-Id: Icf7ba18121547ba7ea37fdefdb3c9510aeb1654e

Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

commit_message:
Add password authentification in monasca-api with Cassandra

Add the support to configure user and password in monasca api and enforce
the authetification when connecting to cassandra db when the user and
password is set.

Change-Id: I9e6689e0e8e6e97d5cff3a59aecb53483ec320bd
story: 2001471
task: 6191

messages: [{'account_id': 538, 'date': '2018-01-31 18:46:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-02-01 10:01:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-01 10:02:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-31 18:46:43.000000000', 'message': 'Fix SELinux policy filenames

Within the SELinux policy file itself, the policy is referenced
as `osa-neutron`, but the filename for the policy did not match.
This patch fixes the filenames to match the policy name.

Closes-Bug: 1742552
Change-Id: I52901ac48f9a95d0fe6b010f5940b5c39fce1aba
'}]
commit_message:
Fix SELinux policy filenames

Within the SELinux policy file itself, the policy is referenced
as `osa-neutron`, but the filename for the policy did not match.
This patch fixes the filenames to match the policy name.

Closes-Bug: 1742552
Change-Id: I52901ac48f9a95d0fe6b010f5940b5c39fce1aba

commit_message:
Cover string representations of api_versions.APIVersion

Adding unit-tests to check string representation and repr()
results for api_versions.APIVersion instances.
Both for valid versions and null.

This increases code coverage.

Change-Id: I53125c0f993a54812d47341c7956222b7da65c7f
Partial-Bug: #1364800

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.

'}]
commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I89687aa13dc307431c28fa3c4fb190daf0a79fee

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-31 15:51:21.000000000', 'message': "Add missing ilo vendor to the ilo hardware types

I'm not sure why it was missed initially. But if we don't have it,
the automatic migration to hardware types will reset the vendor
interface to no-vendor, which may look like a regression to users.

Change-Id: I6da6aa8138d7f0cbf225c15c4137edeec2c33d49
Related-Bug: #1690185
"}]
commit_message:
Add missing ilo vendor to the ilo hardware types

I'm not sure why it was missed initially. But if we don't have it,
the automatic migration to hardware types will reset the vendor
interface to no-vendor, which may look like a regression to users.

Change-Id: I6da6aa8138d7f0cbf225c15c4137edeec2c33d49
Related-Bug: #1690185

Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

commit_message:
Clean imports in code

In some part in the code we import objects. In the Openstack style guidelines
they recommend to import only modules. [1]: "Do not import objects, only modules".

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/hacking/0.10.3/

Change-Id: I55ec09ba2977a973d384d6387958ec0972f581ec

commit_message:
Add scope_types to endpoint group policies

This commit adds scope types for all endpoint group policies. Since
endpoints are considered a system-level resource, it makes sense to
associate system scope to endpoint group policies.

From now on, a warning will be logged when a project-scoped token is
used to manage endpoint groups. Operators can opt into requiring
system-scoped tokens for these policies by enabling oslo.policy's
`enforce_scope` configuration option, which will result in an HTTP
Forbidden exception when mismatching scope is detected.

Change-Id: Icae41a1c5ce88754f0163970431a411529c3b8fe

commit_message:
add 'tags' in request body of projects

first, add 'tags' in request body of projects when create
and update.
second, put necessary parameter 'name'in first place when
create and update for convenience.

Change-Id: I46a20c3e36dc47db3ec20d39da9036f19e5e4e5c

commit_message:
Add python-tripleoclient subpackage(s) from delorean-current

https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/11700  has created a new
package python-tripleoclient-container. This must be installed
from delorean-current as python-tripleoclient when deploying in
TripleO CI.

Change-Id: Ic267f6f4157abc59b64b66b7395607539bedbca9

commit_message:
Replace xml defusedxml

xml was considered as vulnerable to different atacks.
It is recommended to replace this library with defused_xml

Change-Id: I2b146dc34ada37a3ed9ecf49513d024a8ca2fb19
Related-Bug: #1625402

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-05 12:43:18.000000000', 'message': 'Add test case for group type specs APIs

Group type specs APIs (min_microversion is 3.11) are implemented in v3
volume group types. These APIs has not been tested in Tempest yet, and
this patch adds test case for the new features.

Including:

[1] Add group type specs APIs to v3 group_types_client
[2] Add unit tests for group type specs APIs
[3] Add test case: test_group_type_specs_create_show_update_delete
[4] Add release note

Change-Id: Ie7c8dd06238e111cdf691f083500018d066dd689

commit_message:
Add test case for group type specs APIs

Group type specs APIs (min_microversion is 3.11) are implemented in v3
volume group types. These APIs has not been tested in Tempest yet, and
this patch adds test case for the new features.

Including:

[1] Add group type specs APIs to v3 group_types_client
[2] Add unit tests for group type specs APIs
[3] Add test case: test_group_type_specs_create_show_update_list_delete
[4] Add release note

Change-Id: Ie7c8dd06238e111cdf691f083500018d066dd689

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-26 01:33:55.000000000', 'message': 'Support fabric specific Cisco FC Zone Name
This change in Fibre Channel zone manager Cisco driver allows to use the
Fibre Channel fabric level cisco_zone_name_prefix to form the zone name.
This is consistent with the "Cisco Fibre Channel Zone Driver – OpenStack
Configuration Reference”. Zone_name_prefix will fall back to the one
speficied at fc-zone-manager level if it is not specified at the more
granular FC fabric level. The existing code takes zone_name_prefix only
from the fc-zone-manager configuration.

This patch also removes the code that marks Cisco Fibre Channel Zone driver
as unsupported and deprecated. Cisco CI has been up and running again since
Jan 24, 2018. Thus the change.

This patch also contains a minor cleanup in ssh pool.

Change-Id: If629dd30ed61829a1e4a56bc2e4401ef1adef2a5

commit_message:
Support fabric specific Cisco FC Zone Name

This change in Fibre Channel zone manager Cisco driver allows to use the
Fibre Channel fabric level cisco_zone_name_prefix to form the zone name.
This is consistent with the "Cisco Fibre Channel Zone Driver – OpenStack
Configuration Reference”. Zone_name_prefix will fall back to the one
speficied at fc-zone-manager level if it is not specified at the more
granular FC fabric level. The existing code takes zone_name_prefix only
from the fc-zone-manager configuration.

This patch also removes the code that marks Cisco Fibre Channel Zone driver
as unsupported and deprecated. Cisco CI has been up and running again since
Jan 24, 2018. Thus the change.

This patch also contains a minor cleanup in ssh pool.

Change-Id: If629dd30ed61829a1e4a56bc2e4401ef1adef2a5

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I78e3910214f33f7422f59971e290a48f369a166a

commit_message:
ComputeDriver.update_provider_tree()

Introduce a new compute driver abstract method, update_provider_tree.

This method takes a ProviderTree object, giving the virt driver the
opportunity to update its hierarchy and inventory.

It supersedes get_inventory().

Change-Id: I3521b3b038a9df16e600083505a94da5f9790c2f
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-17 15:07:57.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Scheduler[Report]Client.get_provider_tree

SchedulerReportClient.get_provider_tree retrieves from the placement API
all providers associated with a specified provider via its nested tree
or aggregates.  It returns a fresh ProviderTree populated with these
providers and their inventory.  This is the data structure which will be
passed into the virt driver's update_provider_tree method.

A SchedulerClient.get_provider_tree wrapper is also provided.

WIP: SchedulerClient.get_provider_tree
WIP: Tests

Change-Id: I9469dec80c2b357185645ef1705f098f25dcb8c8
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

SchedulerReportClient.get_provider_tree retrieves from the placement API
all providers associated with a specified provider via its nested tree
or aggregates.  It returns a fresh ProviderTree populated with these
providers and their inventory.  This is the data structure which will be
passed into the virt driver's update_provider_tree method.

A SchedulerClient.get_provider_tree wrapper is also provided.

WIP: I think the bulk of this logic needs to get folded into
_ensure_resource_provider and/or broken down into smaller helpers.  So
we fully (re)populate the client's _provider_tree as we go; and then
get_provider_tree itself would just return a copy of that already-built
_provider_tree.

Change-Id: I9469dec80c2b357185645ef1705f098f25dcb8c8

"}, {'created': '2018-01-18 19:48:37.000000000', 'message': "report client: get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root

SchedulerReportClient.get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root retrieves from
the placement API all providers associated with a specified provider via
its nested tree or aggregates.  It returns a fresh ProviderTree
populated with these providers and their inventory.  This is the data
structure which will be passed into the virt driver's
update_provider_tree method.

In its current incarnation, this method will create and/or load into
cache the root provider (associated with the compute node) if not
already present.  This is because the resource tracker is currently
structured to handle init and update in the same code path.  At some
point in the future we may want to split that out and make this method
*just* return a deepcopy of the cache.

Change-Id: I9469dec80c2b357185645ef1705f098f25dcb8c8
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
"}, {'created': '2018-01-19 15:43:12.000000000', 'message': "report client: get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root

SchedulerReportClient.get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root retrieves from
the placement API all providers associated with a specified provider via
its tree or aggregates.  It returns a fresh ProviderTree populated with
these providers and their inventory.  This is the data structure which
will be passed into the virt driver's update_provider_tree method.

In its current incarnation, this method will create and/or load into
cache the root provider (associated with the compute node) if not
already present.  This is because the resource tracker is currently
structured to handle init and update in the same code path.  At some
point in the future we may want to split that out and make this method
*just* return a deepcopy of the cache.

Change-Id: I9469dec80c2b357185645ef1705f098f25dcb8c8

commit_message:
report client: get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root

SchedulerReportClient.get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root retrieves from
the placement API all providers associated with a specified provider via
its tree or aggregates.  It returns a fresh ProviderTree populated with
these providers and their inventory.  This is the data structure which
will be passed into the virt driver's update_provider_tree method.

In its current incarnation, this method will create and/or load into
cache the root provider (associated with the compute node) if not
already present.  This is because the resource tracker is currently
structured to handle init and update in the same code path.  At some
point in the future we may want to split that out and make this method
*just* return a deepcopy of the cache.

Change-Id: I9469dec80c2b357185645ef1705f098f25dcb8c8
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-22 04:27:26.000000000', 'message': 'Fix bug case by none token context

When set reclaim_instance_interval > 0, and then delete an
instance which booted from volume with `delete_on_termination`
set as true. After reclaim_instance_interval time pass,
all volumes boot instance will with state: attached and in-use,
but attached instances was deleted.

So add user/project CONF with admin role at cinder group,
and when determine context is_admin and without token, do
authenticaion with user/project info to call cinder api.

Change-Id: I3c35bba43fee81baebe8261f546c1424ce3a3383
Closes-Bugs: #1733736
'}, {'created': '2017-11-22 06:55:52.000000000', 'message': 'Fix bug case by none token context

When set reclaim_instance_interval > 0, and then delete an
instance which booted from volume with `delete_on_termination`
set as true. After reclaim_instance_interval time pass,
all volumes boot instance will with state: attached and in-use,
but attached instances was deleted.

This bug case as admin context from
`nova.compute.manager._reclaim_queued_deletes` did not have
any token info, then call cinder api would be failed.

So add user/project CONF with admin role at cinder group,
and when determine context is_admin and without token, do
authenticaion with user/project info to call cinder api.

Change-Id: I3c35bba43fee81baebe8261f546c1424ce3a3383
Closes-Bugs: #1733736

commit_message:
Fix bug case by none token context

When set reclaim_instance_interval > 0, and then delete an
instance which booted from volume with `delete_on_termination`
set as true. After reclaim_instance_interval time pass,
all volumes boot instance will with state: attached and in-use,
but attached instances was deleted.

This bug case as admin context from
`nova.compute.manager._reclaim_queued_deletes` did not have
any token info, then call cinder api would be failed.

So add user/project CONF with admin role at cinder group,
and when determine context is_admin and without token, do
authenticaion with user/project info to call cinder api.

Change-Id: I3c35bba43fee81baebe8261f546c1424ce3a3383
Closes-Bug: #1733736
Closes-Bug: #1734025
Partial-Bug: #1736773

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-01 00:09:42.000000000', 'message': 'make ec2-api job as n-v

Due to split the neutron-tempest-plugin and
switching neutron-vpnaas to use new plugin causing
ec2-api gate is broken.

Which block the job migration to ec2-api repo
where we move the job from infra to ec2-api and
also fix the tempest plugin usage.
Both things have to go together as migrated jobs fail due to above
issue.
- I9c88ac1ecf0368c9ea7a8b20c84995ea29487184

To unblock this circular fixes, this patch makes
legacy job as n-v so that job migration patch can be merged.

Change-Id: Ic0ffe26ced252bc195ead4affa1599a953645970
'}]
commit_message:
make ec2-api job as n-v

Due to split the neutron-tempest-plugin and
switching neutron-vpnaas to use new plugin causing
ec2-api gate is broken.

Which block the job migration to ec2-api repo
where we move the job from infra to ec2-api and
also fix the tempest plugin usage.
Both things have to go together as migrated jobs fail due to above
issue.
- I9c88ac1ecf0368c9ea7a8b20c84995ea29487184

To unblock this circular fixes, this patch makes
legacy job as n-v so that job migration patch can be merged.

Change-Id: Ic0ffe26ced252bc195ead4affa1599a953645970

commit_message:
Make the restart_policy visiable for capsule

Also change the property for restart_policy in capsule
to align with Kubernetes.

Part of blueprint golang-client

Change-Id: I0bf08a080355b950ff9f1eac9cc90a39eca17b48
Signed-off-by: Kevin Zhao <kevin.zhao@arm.com>

commit_message:
Fix IPSec docs on how to change the encryption algorithm

The variable documented didn't merge, and IpsecVars is going to be used
in favor of it.

Change-Id: Ibbfad62f951c5574a13a581fcbecbb959d7eba24
Depends-On: Ie6ef4aa05567c739884c1d402fc59eea80b31506

commit_message:
Handle images with no data

There isn't really much we can do with these images, which glance tells
us are possible [1]. Simply raise an exception.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/python-glanceclient/latest/reference/api/glanceclient.v2.images.html

Change-Id: I5f81393a5bb41e6a674369afb899d8a41bb2c3b4
Closes-Bug: #1736759
(cherry picked from commit c10a614e92d15280f05574d82bbede6df6aaeec6)

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ied28450241447d6cb4868b61279e41792a423498

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-19 02:49:04.000000000', 'message': "Add '[Docs]' tag to bug report summary

This commit adds '[Docs]' tag to a bug report summary by default. For
openstackdocstheme, most of bugs would be documentation bugs. So, this
could be convenient for a bug reporter and also for developer who
triages bugs.

Change-Id: Ib8a02c16c426529c4fb64e390dc83e7bcbb0529a
"}]
commit_message:
Add '[Docs]' tag to bug report summary

This commit adds '[Docs]' tag to a bug report summary by default. For
openstackdocstheme, most of bugs would be documentation bugs. So, this
could be convenient for a bug reporter and also for developer who
triages bugs.

Change-Id: Ib8a02c16c426529c4fb64e390dc83e7bcbb0529a
