This commit explains the incompatibility:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/323590/'}, {'account_id': 26895, 'date': '2018-01-26 16:23:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 26895, 'date': '2018-01-26 16:26:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

You need to change trovescript datastore version for cassandra.

I updated it when I fixed the element install script which was failing.'}, {'account_id': 18665, 'date': '2018-01-26 16:47:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26895, 'date': '2018-01-26 16:59:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 26895, 'date': '2018-01-26 17:00:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

check experimental'}, {'account_id': 26895, 'date': '2018-01-26 20:52:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

check experimental'}, {'account_id': 26895, 'date': '2018-01-27 01:24:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

@Pierre, Please note that cassandra is failing.  If you search for do_prepare in the log file [1] you will see that there is a setup issue of some kind.  You should see the same error in the integration tests which is easier to debug.   

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/09/537009/2/experimental/trove-scenario-cassandra-single/f6b7bcb/logs/devstack-gate-post_test_hook.txt.gz'}, {'account_id': 18665, 'date': '2018-01-27 23:58:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Luke, All my test was done on trusty. I am not sure cassandra works on xenial.'}, {'account_id': 18665, 'date': '2018-01-28 00:00:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

with these current elements (of course Cassandra should works on xenial)'}, {'account_id': 26895, 'date': '2018-01-29 15:38:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I tested this on Xenial using the integration tests and it creates an instance.  The wait for instance create step completed successfully and then there were errors relates to mysql which shouldn't be included in the integration tests for cassandra.  That is a problem with the integration tests.

The experimental gate tests cassandra and it shows an error on Xenial that needs to be investigated [1].

commit_message:
Revert Cassandra version to 2 on ubuntu element

The element is configured to use version 3 of cassandra, unfortunatly
trove is actually not compatible with version 3.

Closes-Bug: #1745056
Change-Id: Ic22202eeae6f404433a84def8cf5da0e5dc28c7b

commit_message:
tests: Use correct response type in tests

An instance of 'glanceclient.utils.common.RequestIdProxy' is returned
for most calls to glanceclient. Correct the unit tests to reflect this.

- https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/2.8.0/glanceclient/common/utils.py#L542
- https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/2.8.0/glanceclient/v2/images.py#L199

Change-Id: I1a0a7c80d6ca53d0ac8821b2e63dd43593e6c822
(cherry picked from commit 646264f3b92606359b0f5b0e0970e494a0f65dba)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-19 05:47:08.000000000', 'message': 'Handle TZ change in iso8601 >=1.12.0

The iso8601 lib introduced a change such that if running on python
3.2 or later it internally uses the python timezone information
instead of its own implementation. This does not change direct
date handling, but when converting this value there is a slight
difference where now python 2.x will show UTC times as "UTC",
but on python 3 they will end up with "UTC+00:00".

The to_primitive call for DateTime fields was doing an exact match
on "UTC" to determine whether to include "Z" in the resulting string.
This updates that handling to recognize either of the new values

Change-Id: Icb29d71472932f3ddfe485298d1a5fdd08be6f12
Closes-bug: #1744160
'}, {'created': '2018-01-19 09:41:50.000000000', 'message': 'Handle TZ change in iso8601 >=1.12.0

commit_message:
Handle TZ change in iso8601 >=0.1.12

The iso8601 lib introduced a change such that if running on python
3.2 or later it internally uses the python timezone information
instead of its own implementation. This does not change direct
date handling, but when converting this value there is a slight
difference where now python 2.x will show UTC times as "UTC",
but on python 3 they will end up with "UTC+00:00".

The to_primitive call for DateTime fields was doing an exact match
on "UTC" to determine whether to include "Z" in the resulting string.
This updates that handling to recognize either of the new values

Change-Id: Icb29d71472932f3ddfe485298d1a5fdd08be6f12
Closes-bug: #1744160

While I am here, I've noticed there is no exlanation in commit body as to why this change is required. This is what my -1 is for. I do not know what commit practices keystone project enforces and I am not active reviewer on the project, but explaining the change is a good practice in any case."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-12-07 21:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

 > not know what commit practices keystone project enforces and I am
 > not active reviewer on the project, but explaining the change is a
 > good practice in any case.

Thanks for the note, I'll be sure to recheck in groups next time.

I agree about the commit message. My goal was to push these for review and generate a discussion among reviewers since this is part of a multi-release roadmap for improving security across OpenStack.

commit_message:
Add scope_types to policy association policies

This commit associates `system` to all policy association policies.
Since policy association can be done to endpoints and services, which
are system-level resources, it makes sense to require system-scoped
tokens to make those associations.

From now on, a warning will be logged when a project-scoped token is
used to make policy associations to endpoints or services. Operators
will have the option to require system-scoped tokens for these
policies by enabling oslo.policy's `enforce_scope` configuration
option.

Change-Id: I18692cd14f9c57816da173038d7dd9ff0802246a

commit_message:
Add scope_types to token revocation policies

This doesn't seem useful since the API will return an empty list
regardless because PKI support has been removed.

More or less doing this for consistency.

Change-Id: Iaa2925119fa6c9e2324546ed44aa54bac51dba05

commit_message:
Add scope_types to project endpoint policies

This commit gives all project endpoint policies a scope type of
`system` since endpoints are system-level resources.

From now on, a warning will be logged when a project-scoped token is
used to manage project endpoint associations. Operators will have the
option to require system-scoped tokens for these policies by enabling
oslo.policy's `enforce_scope` configuration option, which will result
in an HTTP Forbidden exception when mismatching scope is detected.

Change-Id: I23b12f9a4cfbb124a6ea2cc55b5c0ccb2d463ae8

the projects resource. This commit writes those down so that we have
something to shoot for and track.

commit_message:
Document fixes needed for token scope_types

Token policies are complex. In order to make sure we don't regress
we need to make sure we incorporate proper scope checks in code
before uncommenting the scope_types for token policies.

Change-Id: I9a2890688c9d3a3daf1bc872eed34d02a56d223d

Replace base functional tearDown with addCleanup

addCleanup will run all cleanups, even if one of them throws an
exception.

commit_message:
placement: enable required traits from the flavor extra specs

This patch enables the flavor extra spec 'required:[traits]'. The
admin can specifiy a set of traits that a flavor required.

To enable this, the placement 1.17 is required, it added trait
support in the `GET /allocation_candidates` API. So bump the
minimal placement version requirement to 1.17 and update the
check in cmd `nova-status`.

Implement blueprint request-traits-in-nova

Change-Id: Ia51ace951e9a0402f873ce9751a8cd3c0283db08

commit_message:
Add functional tests for virt driver get_traits() method

Test that starting up a compute node will successfully put traits into
the placement engine.

Change-Id: Ica5453b3c5418df75cad8505efc37686b57bc6ff

Implement the get_traits() method for the ironic virt driver. This
allows ironic nodes with traits set to have those traits registered
with the approriate resource provider in the placement API.

The ironic client version has been bumped to 1.37 in order to query

commit_message:
Implement get_traits() for the ironic virt driver

Implement the get_traits() method for the ironic virt driver. This
allows ironic nodes with traits set to have those traits registered
with the approriate resource provider in the placement API.

The ironic client version has been bumped to 1.37 in order to query
nodes' traits.

blueprint ironic-driver-traits

Change-Id: I4065b61edff8bfd66a163c9ccf19833316fdca8e
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/538066

commit_message:
Fix the default value of stage_dir

The current default value of stage_dir does not match the valid
default from zuul-jobs, which causes stackviz to be skipped when
stage_dir is not overwritten, which is the case in all CI jobs.

Setting default and docs to "{{ ansible_user_dir }}".

Change-Id: I9fd3f8541c8e3fbc406c5e5c0c5fe8427bf74112

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-05 16:06:00.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Re-initialise volumes, encryptors, and vifs on hard reboot

We call _hard_reboot during reboot, power_on, and
resume_state_on_host_boot. It functions essentially by tearing as much
of an instance as possible before recreating it, which additionally
makes it useful to operators for attempting automated recovery of
instances in an inconsistent state.

The Libvirt driver would previously only call _destroy and
_undefine_domain when hard rebooting an instance. This would leave vifs
plugged, volumes connected, and encryptors attached on the host. It
also means that when we try to restart the instance, we assume all
these things are correctly configured. If they are not, the instance
may fail to start at all, or may be incorrectly configured when
starting.

For example, consider an instance with an encrypted volume after a
compute host reboot. When we attempt to start the instance, power_on
will call _hard_reboot. The volume will be coincidentally re-attached
as a side-effect of calling _get_guest_xml(!), but when we call
_create_domain_and_network we pass reboot=True, which tells it not to
reattach the encryptor, as it is assumed to be already attached. We
are therefore left presenting the encrypted volume data directly to
the instance without decryption.

The approach in this patch is to ensure we recreate the instance as
fully as possible during hard reboot. This means not passing
vifs_already_plugged and reboot to _create_domain_and_network, which
in turn requires that we fully destroy the instance first. This
addresses the specific problem given in the example, but also a whole
class of potential volume and vif related issues of inconsistent
state.

Because we now always tear down volumes, encryptors, and vifs, we are
relying on the tear down of these things to be idempotent.  This
highlighted that detach of the luks and cryptsetup encryptors were not
idempotent. We depend on the fixes for those os-brick drivers.

Depends-On: I31d72357c89db53a147c2d986a28c9c6870efad0
Depends-On: I9f52f89b8466d03699cfd5c0e32c672c934cd6fb

Closes-bug: #1724573
Change-Id: Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986
(cherry picked from commit 3f8daf080411b84ec0669f0642524ce8a7d19057)

commit_message:
libvirt: Re-initialise volumes, encryptors, and vifs on hard reboot

We call _hard_reboot during reboot, power_on, and
resume_state_on_host_boot. It functions essentially by tearing as much
of an instance as possible before recreating it, which additionally
makes it useful to operators for attempting automated recovery of
instances in an inconsistent state.

The Libvirt driver would previously only call _destroy and
_undefine_domain when hard rebooting an instance. This would leave vifs
plugged, volumes connected, and encryptors attached on the host. It
also means that when we try to restart the instance, we assume all
these things are correctly configured. If they are not, the instance
may fail to start at all, or may be incorrectly configured when
starting.

For example, consider an instance with an encrypted volume after a
compute host reboot. When we attempt to start the instance, power_on
will call _hard_reboot. The volume will be coincidentally re-attached
as a side-effect of calling _get_guest_xml(!), but when we call
_create_domain_and_network we pass reboot=True, which tells it not to
reattach the encryptor, as it is assumed to be already attached. We
are therefore left presenting the encrypted volume data directly to
the instance without decryption.

The approach in this patch is to ensure we recreate the instance as
fully as possible during hard reboot. This means not passing
vifs_already_plugged and reboot to _create_domain_and_network, which
in turn requires that we fully destroy the instance first. This
addresses the specific problem given in the example, but also a whole
class of potential volume and vif related issues of inconsistent
state.

Because we now always tear down volumes, encryptors, and vifs, we are
relying on the tear down of these things to be idempotent.  This
highlighted that detach of the luks and cryptsetup encryptors were not
idempotent. We depend on the fixes for those os-brick drivers.

NOTE(melwitt): Instead of depending on the os-brick changes to handle
the "already detached" scenario during cleanup for the stable
backports, we handle it in the driver since we can't bump g-r for
stable branches.

Closes-bug: #1724573
Change-Id: Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986
(cherry picked from commit 3f8daf080411b84ec0669f0642524ce8a7d19057)

commit_message:
Revert "Integration of (Distributed) Port Binding OVO"

This reverts commit febeaf5d4016157d0cca41023e64b91e550453e8.

This patch broke postgres tempest jobs, as well as introduced potential
race conditions in database layer because of mixed usage of old and new
engine facades.

Related-Bug: #1744829
Change-Id: Ic142ae7faf4e5f10cbdf761d7e6f3d442e94a3eb

commit_message:
[placement] Separate API schemas (resource_provider)

In compute APIs, they have their schemas in the
independent directory (nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas).
Placement APIs should be like that as well.

This patch separates API schemas to an independent directory
(nova/api/openstack/placement/schemas)
from nova/api/openstack/placement/handlers/resource_provider.py.

Change-Id: I49f101723e9defcfc30b159759f1c1b7687bccf4

commit_message:
Return stack.outputs when stack in DELETE_FAILED

Users can not view outputs of stacks in DELETE_FAILED.
But it's useful for magnum to get cluster info from stack.outputs
and for users to debug failed stacks.

Change-Id: Ib3927c61660b1b2162d5b34809b48401062a6f02
Close-Bug: #1712274

commit_message:
Remove unused policy cp in devstack

We won't have policy.json file by default anymore, so we don't need
this `cp` command.

Implements: bp policy-in-code

Change-Id: I84c99e38c34dc41cc33126291563ea90038ce107

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I821e7f472112907f07f7d77b7de25ba700079d9c

> > (2 comments)

 > 
 > Please read the error here, I feel it should be caused by the
 > mistake here.

 > https://review.openstack.org/#/c/536217/
 > 
 > 
 > 
 > also,I find this change merged 2 days ago,this led SQLAlchemy to an
 > update to version 1.2.1, presumably and our gate broken mildly

jiansong, thanks for privoding the log. This has been merged, sorry for the late response, I did more tests for this, yes, the root cause is the uprade of SQLAlchemy to 1.2.1. In the new version of SQLAlchemy, boolean is strictly check, however this behavior is not the same across all database engine backend.

At first I did all debugging in the trove-manage command line and it worked well, because the devstack environment use mysql as the database backend. However the unittests use sqlite, and calling 'update_datastore_version' failed.

I still think the commit message should be more accurate to state what the problem is and how it's been fixed. Anyway the patch works, thanks for fixing this."}, {'account_id': 22694, 'date': '2018-02-01 06:15:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Fix gate error

Looks like SQLAlchemy in version 1.2.x checks if the boolean value
is None, True, False, 1, or 0. We used a "1" in our test, which
does not seem to meet the requirements. In the meantime, if we
change it to 1 here, our function section needs to be changed
as well.

Change-Id: I8df2118fee12fd9dd02caf96a23bc59652efbed7

TBH I was fairly happy with my suggested changes to find_best_match() from patch set 36, and the prospect of starting again with a completely new implementation that reintroduces all of the old inefficiencies we just managed to get rid of, plus makes me figure out everything from scratch again to check for regressions, makes me *really* unmotivated to review this properly.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2017-12-19 10:04:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42:

(8 comments)

I tried to do this as you suggested, but I could'nt figure out how to make it work. I was frustrated too. Let my try to explain why I could'nt figure it out.

If we did:
  for old_net in list(old_nets):
      match = self.find_best_match(new_nets, old_net)

  Would have to do the reduce bit of each new_net inside the
  find_best_match. The reduce code is done differently in
  the two methods using the shared find_best_match, so I fail to
  see how to make a good generic shared method. How would I reduce
  the new_nets outside the common implementation, when we pass
  new_nets to the common implentation and iterate over it in the
  common implementation?

The algorithm used to find matches was different in update_networks_matching_iface_port() and _exclude_not_updated_networks() before the shared find_match.

 In _exclude...():
   for new_net in list(new_nets):
     (reduce the new net)
     if self.NETWORK_PORT in new_net:
       for old_net in old_nets:         <-- iterate over old_nets
          ...
     if self.NETWORK_FIXED_IP in new_net:
       for old_net in old_nets:
          ...

 In update...(): (Previous find_best_match)

    for net in nets:
      (Create net_props - The neutron qualified data in template property format)
      if net_props[self.NETWORK_PORT]:
        ...
      if net_props[self.NETWORK_FIXED_IP]:
        ....

In the latter case there is no iteration of the "reference nets"? (old_nets/neutron interfaces) inside the find match function.

I ended up using the algorithm used in _exclude..() and change update...() to create the "net_props" outside the find_best_match().'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2017-12-19 10:05:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 43.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2017-12-19 13:32:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 43:

recheck

Timeout issue in snapshot restore tests.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2017-12-19 20:37:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 43: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

> Would have to do the reduce bit of each new_net inside the find_best_match.

Could have reduced it beforehand (there's no data in the non-reduced version that find_best_match() needs), but yeah I can see it would be a pain since you have to find the original, non-reduced version in the list and remove it.

> The algorithm used to find matches was different in update_networks_matching_iface_port() and _exclude_not_updated_networks() before the shared find_match.

Right, but that wasn't a Good Thing ;)

> In the latter case there is no iteration of the "reference nets"? (old_nets/neutron interfaces) inside the find match function.

I mean... they're both nested for loops, just with the inner and outer loop swapped.

This way seems to be working out though. I was more grumpy than usual yesterday after being out sick for much of last week.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2017-12-20 01:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 44.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2017-12-20 01:25:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 43:

(2 comments)

Cool, this is looking pretty good! Here's what I suggest to get some more reviews: split it into at least 3 patches:

- Make whatever changes are necessary to existing unit tests (these should still work with the old code)
- Refactor update_networks_matching_iface_port() to use the new find_best_match() function (without the last else case)
- Add the else case, use find_best_match() in _exclude_not_updated_networks(), and add unit tests for the new fixes + functional tests.

If the last one can meaningfully be split up any further (e.g. if finding the best subset intersection in find_best_match() solves some identifiable subset of the problem without changing _exclude_not_updated_networks() - I don't know if it does) then I would do that too."}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2017-12-21 14:58:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 46.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2017-12-21 15:15:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 45:

'}, {'created': '2017-06-26 23:09:09.000000000', 'message': "Exclude updated networks - match actual interface state

Use the existing logic in update_networks_matching_iface_port() to
populate old_nets with implicit values from interfaces before matching
new_nets properties. The network is not updated if added properties match
what is currently on the interface.

Without this chanage a stack created with...

    networks:
      - network: net0

... then updated with...

    networks:
      - network: net0
        subnet: subnet0

... would result in a port replace, which is not neccecary if the
implicit subnet used when the stack was initially created was also
'subnet0'. The port being replaced will result in neutron re-running
ipam and the ip_address associated would change.

  With the introducton of routed networks in neutron the ipam code
  changed to defer ip allocation unless either the binding:host_id or
  fixed_ips is set in the port create request.
  (ref: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1695740)

  Since the Heat OS::Nova::Server: resource creates ports by calling
  neutron before calling nova to create the server instance, a Heat
  user will have to specify either subnet or a fixed_ip in case they
  need get_attr in their templates to reference IP addresses associated
  with the server instance elswhere in the templates.

Closes-Bug: #1696483
Change-Id: Iab75ec49b962617943017dcaf1b04b89f91a982e
Implements: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-deployment

        subnet: subnet0

... would result in a port replace, which is not necessary if the
implicit subnet used when the stack was initially created was also
'subnet0'. The port being replaced will result in neutron re-running
ipam and the ip_address associated would change.

  With the introducton of routed networks in neutron the ipam code
  changed to defer ip allocation unless either the binding:host_id or
  fixed_ips is set in the port create request.
  (ref: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1695740)

  Since the Heat OS::Nova::Server: resource creates ports by calling
  neutron before calling nova to create the server instance, a Heat
  user will have to specify either subnet or a fixed_ip in case they
  need get_attr in their templates to reference IP addresses associated
  with the server instance elswhere in the templates.

Closes-Bug: #1696483
Closes-Bug: #1702279
Change-Id: Iab75ec49b962617943017dcaf1b04b89f91a982e
Implements: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-deployment

"}, {'created': '2017-12-09 21:27:25.000000000', 'message': "Exclude updated networks - match actual interface state

Use the existing logic in update_networks_matching_iface_port() to
populate old_nets with implicit values from interfaces before
matching new_nets properties. The network is not updated if added
properties match what is currently on the interface.

Without this chanage a stack created with...

    networks:
      - network: net0

... then updated with...

    networks:
      - network: net0
        subnet: subnet0

... would result in a port replace, which is not necessary if the
implicit subnet used when the stack was initially created was also
'subnet0'. The port being replaced will result in neutron re-running
ipam and the ip_address associated would change.

Closes-Bug: #1696483
Closes-Bug: #1702279
Depends-On: Idda07743344277d119cdac46022fab05bbd2b973
Change-Id: Iab75ec49b962617943017dcaf1b04b89f91a982e
Implements: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-deployment

commit_message:
Exclude updated networks - match actual interface state

Use update_networks_matching_iface_port() to populate old_nets
with implicit values from interfaces before matching new_nets
properties. The network is not updated if added properties match
what is currently on the interface.

Without this chanage a stack created with...

    networks:
      - network: net0

... then updated with...

    networks:
      - network: net0
        subnet: subnet0

... would result in a port replace, which is not necessary if the
implicit subnet used when the stack was initially created was also
'subnet0'. The port being replaced will result in neutron re-running
ipam and the ip_address associated would change.

Closes-Bug: #1696483
Closes-Bug: #1702279
Depends-On: Ic4bbbcc3cee329a4de8f0eac710128175c4fc397
Change-Id: Iab75ec49b962617943017dcaf1b04b89f91a982e
Implements: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-deployment

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2018-02-01 06:02:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for your comment! Yeah, it works like below.

 $ tempest workspace remove --name cloud01 --rmdir
 $ tempest init cloud01

But if we run it in the workspace directory, it might be a bit complicated.

 $ tempest init cloud01
 $ cd cloud01
 $ tempest workspace remove --name cloud01 --rmdir
 $ tempest init .
 shell-init: error retrieving current directory: getcwd: cannot access parent directories: No such file or directory
 <SNIP>

But hmm, your suggestion is reasonable. I think I can think the workflow a bit more.

So, I'll abandon this anyway."}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2018-02-01 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-30 08:09:19.000000000', 'message': "Add force option for tempest init command

This commit adds --force/-f option for `tempest init`
command. When we want to re-use a tempest directory, we need to do
like this::

  $ rm -rf cloud01
  $ tempest init cloud01

Otherwise, we'd get an error like below::

  OSError: Directory you are trying to initialize
  already exists and is not empty: cloud01

To reduce this annoying, this 'force' option might be useful.

Change-Id: I513d61c67be6ce3acc21ef61c3bb029eb05549fe
"}]
commit_message:
Add force option for tempest init command

This commit adds --force/-f option for `tempest init`
command. When we want to re-use a tempest directory, we need to do
like this::

  $ rm -rf cloud01
  $ tempest init cloud01

Otherwise, we'd get an error like below::

  OSError: Directory you are trying to initialize
  already exists and is not empty: cloud01

To reduce this annoying, this 'force' option might be useful.

Change-Id: I513d61c67be6ce3acc21ef61c3bb029eb05549fe

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I34259ac65c142ba528a65115c92ec9726368314a

commit_message:
Add back client module

The removal of the Client module breaks downstream consumers such as
heat. This patch adds it back.

Change-Id: I422bd6e9ab0cbb985380f1b898435344f1dd8ac9

commit_message:
Remove sqlalchemy-migrate legacy tox job

The job moves in-repo in https://review.openstack.org/538592, remove it
here. The job is made non-voting in that repo while voting here - and
failing right now. Fixing needs some work, so let's remove this here for
now and let the repo enable it themselves.

Change-Id: Icf58f9bd4bad66f33058c924ae6e325d113f944a

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2017-02-24 15:59:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Since the bug is file about `consistent with regex specified in keystone` do you think it will better if we do target the bug's issue? :)"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2017-02-24 16:07:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

UUID4 has 122 bits of entropy, which should be enough for anyone.

If there's a reason to do this then it's so that Keystone won't start rejecting our passwords. I don't really see the point in having a configuration option, we should have something that's always guaranteed to work."}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2017-02-25 06:01:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@zane, thanks for the review.

There isn't a straightforward way to make sure password generated from Heat will conform to the security compliance. This conformance is not just about whether the password is long (secure) enough. It is more about an audit requirement, say: at least one uppercase character, at least one digit and one special character.

Keystone is exposing this as a config option: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/conf/security_compliance.py#n114

But I don't see a need to directly import that configuration option. Option dependency between projects is not a good thing.

As for using a dead loop for generating password, that is not good. However, I'm not aware of a better way to ensure the password generated is acceptable by Keystone."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2017-02-27 16:22:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Rather than a config option, keystone exposes the password requirements via an API call:

  GET /v3/domains/default/config/security_compliance/password_regex

Is there a way to call that and use the regex pattern there? This will be used in horizon when a user is created / updated.

I believe we have keystoneclient bindings for this API as well.'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2017-02-28 01:49:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

emm, didn't realize there is a keystone api for this. Even if we can probe keystone regex requirement on this, we still need to generate a password string acceptable by keystone."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2017-02-28 04:01:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> emm, didn't realize there is a keystone api for this. Even if we
 > can probe keystone regex requirement on this, we still need to
 > generate a password string acceptable by keystone.

hmm, yes, that a bit of a different flow than expected. for horizon and OSC we would be taking input and validating it against the regex used. 
apparently there's a library called rstr that should make this easy, but it's not in global-requirements:

>>> import rstr
>>> regex = '^(?=.*\d)(?=.*[a-zA-Z]).{7,}$'
>>> rstr.xeger(regex)
u'1o?%N7\x0cf66T\x0bxS<C^PI\t*m1H3p\x0cmNU1,HSHj9M\x0c_*>2^kA5uGmY?1E?AQD^_@c`A&z"0qRJ T}{kh[!JFeza!iyid5F<E.+j|G&R~xeGw\\7y;3&6_'

https://bitbucket.org/leapfrogdevelopment/rstr/'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2017-03-02 16:01:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> There isn't a straightforward way to make sure password generated from Heat will conform to the security compliance. This conformance is not just about whether the password is long (secure) enough. It is more about an audit requirement, say: at least one uppercase character, at least one digit and one special character.

So at least make the default regex require one uppercase character, one digit and one special character. Then it will work out of the box for 99.9% of clouds.

> As for using a dead loop for generating password, that is not good. However, I'm not aware of a better way to ensure the password generated is acceptable by Keystone.

I linked to one in my comment. (Reading the docs for rstr I see that we should be using SystemRandom for this purpose though.)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-06-19 10:54:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 01:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2018-02-01 05:16:33.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

coud not find a way to solve the problem.'}]

commit_message:
Improve server password security compliance

Keystone has introduced a config option for security compliance checking
by validating the user password. This has become a recommended setting
for many customers. The current password generation logic in Heat is too
simple to pass that test (e.g. at least one capitalized character, at
least one digit etc).

This patch replaces the password generation logic and introduces a
config option for this purpose.

Closes-Bug: 1666129
Change-Id: I72308fbb60cb82c2e887b355744d13373c1705ca

commit_message:
Security group quota error handling

When adding a new rule to a secruity group that would exceede the
quota, the error message displays a quota error, rather than rule
already exists error. It does this my first checking for an
"OverQuotaClient" error, then if that except doesn't trigger it
checks for any other conflict

Change-Id: I8eaa0f00b25c8c3b75fef2bf46979f1f248c6896
Closes-Bug: #1699724
(cherry picked from commit 3929a8b7cd893f0b4c0ff6c20d5d1fd9077b4dd2)

subject: Redirect VM console dynamically
messages: [{'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-12-19 12:38:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 25591, 'date': '2017-12-19 13:01:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11885, 'date': '2018-02-01 04:08:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 26552, 'date': '2018-02-01 04:13:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-19 12:38:31.000000000', 'message': 'Redirect VM console dynamically

Previously when a user accesses the network topology panel
horizon resolves VM console URL when returning server data.
This requires one API call to nova per VM, and this causes
a scaling issue.

Actually there is no need to resolves VM console URL when
the network topology. A console URL corresponding to a requested
VM can be resolved when a user actually accesses a console.
This reduces the number of API calls drastically and addresses
the scaling issue reported in the bug report.

Change-Id: Icc667449e2988e6227012a6e899835a97ce0d738
Closes-Bug: #1723142
(cherry picked from commit 974f0418efdf171132747ded4a556df7b7af03d1)
'}]
commit_message:
Redirect VM console dynamically

Previously when a user accesses the network topology panel
horizon resolves VM console URL when returning server data.
This requires one API call to nova per VM, and this causes
a scaling issue.

Actually there is no need to resolves VM console URL when
the network topology. A console URL corresponding to a requested
VM can be resolved when a user actually accesses a console.
This reduces the number of API calls drastically and addresses
the scaling issue reported in the bug report.

Change-Id: Icc667449e2988e6227012a6e899835a97ce0d738
Closes-Bug: #1723142
(cherry picked from commit 974f0418efdf171132747ded4a556df7b7af03d1)

commit_message:
font for transfer table heading enlarged

changed the heading type from h5 to h4 to enlarge it without
altering the appearance of other h5's. This was done because
the current font size made locating the text amongst the many
larger elements on the page, this change allows a user to
quickly identify the purpose of the sections below.

Closes-Bug #1743683

Change-Id: I992ed598d59e4fef6baa18139288782003a1ade3

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ib754a14335fc80fdf1ca292c8c98dfb101a3f58b

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: If928f010c6fd7edb00068a7fa594091dec5ecb0f

commit_message:
i18n: Fix untranslated messages trunk-subports.help.html: The

tag was not closed appropriately. This confused angular-gettext and as a result translations are not used properly. launch-instance/networkports/ports.html: "on subnet" was marked as translation string in bug 1745873, but one "on subnet" is forgot to mark. This commit fixes it. Related-Bug: #1745873 Change-Id: I01c653161c9a91d499bf493590bb5f511901f31a

commit_message:
Add no-vendor interface to the idrac hardware types

Vendor interfaces must not be mandatory. Missing no-vendor implementation
means that we require operators to enable the idrac vendor interface when
the idrac hardware type is enabled.

Change-Id: I6768a37bc268e367eaf93b12660a80d31eeca0c0
Closes-Bug: #1732166
(cherry picked from commit 4432fa9950f8300604528ae9b519bc78db37a768)

commit_message:
Change django.utils.log.NullHandler to logging.NullHandler

django.utils.log.NullHandler was removed in Django 1.9. logging.NullHandler
wad added to Python standard library since 2.7 so we should use it now.

Change-Id: I38f3f1d592f5456efc7dc94c0677a0a594722fbd
(cherry picked from commit b28b8e2b9a31cdef27c1685ec44b4add65eaa167)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-31 13:32:30.000000000', 'message': 'i18n: Do not include html directives in translation strings

It is important not to include html directives in translation targets
as much as possible to avoid unnecessary errors when selecting
translated languages.

Note that this commit does not necessarily exclude all html directives
from translation strings. Some of them needs to be included to allow
translators to control the word order properly.
This commit mainly focuses on eliminate unrelated html directives.

Change-Id: I66a24d4b01e695aab226b7c1cd4bc4f50ab33a7f
'}]
commit_message:
i18n: Do not include html directives in translation strings

It is important not to include html directives in translation targets
as much as possible to avoid unnecessary errors when selecting
translated languages.

Note that this commit does not necessarily exclude all html directives
from translation strings. Some of them needs to be included to allow
translators to control the word order properly.
This commit mainly focuses on eliminate unrelated html directives.

Change-Id: I66a24d4b01e695aab226b7c1cd4bc4f50ab33a7f

[{'created': '2018-01-09 18:24:46.000000000', 'message': 'fix the grub root label when an XFS disk label is truncated

The default disk label of cloudimg-rootfs is truncated to
img-rootfs during the run by diskimage_builder.block_device.level2.mkfs.
However 50-bootloader uses DIB_ROOT_LABEL which has not been truncated.

Change-Id: I41dce6e25766562db4366021309b8c2b74a8ab80
Closes-Bug: 1742170
'}, {'created': '2018-01-19 16:54:28.000000000', 'message': 'fix the grub root label when an XFS disk label is truncated

Change-Id: I41dce6e25766562db4366021309b8c2b74a8ab80
Closes-Bug: 1742170

Change-Id: I41dce6e25766562db4366021309b8c2b74a8ab80
Closes-Bug: 1742170
'}, {'created': '2018-01-25 21:04:35.000000000', 'message': 'fix the grub root label when an XFS disk label is truncated

The default disk label of cloudimg-rootfs is truncated to
img-rootfs during the run by diskimage_builder.block_device.level2.mkfs.
However 50-bootloader uses DIB_ROOT_LABEL which has not been truncated.

Change-Id: I41dce6e25766562db4366021309b8c2b74a8ab80
Closes-Bug: 1742170
'}, {'created': '2018-01-28 23:35:17.000000000', 'message': 'Export DIB_ROOT_LABEL from final state

As described in the test config comment, the default disk label of
cloudimg-rootfs is truncated to img-rootfs for XFS partitions.

The current export examines the raw configuration file and exports the
label from that.  Per above, this is incorrect if it has been
truncated for the XFS case during parsing.

I believe it's a better idea to get this information directly out of
the state dictionary, which reflects the actual (post
configuration-munging) configuration being used.

Because we're getting the values from the state, we need to move the
exports after the "dib-block-device create" call.  This is OK, because
the values are intended for the bootloader elements which run after
this.

The mount/mkfs unit-test is updated to ensure the values are in the
state correctly.

Change-Id: I41dce6e25766562db4366021309b8c2b74a8ab80
Closes-Bug: 1742170
'}, {'created': '2018-01-29 00:19:05.000000000', 'message': 'Export DIB_ROOT_LABEL from final state

As described in the test config comment, the default disk label of
cloudimg-rootfs is truncated to img-rootfs for XFS partitions.

The current export examines the raw configuration file and exports the
label from that.  Per above, this is incorrect if it has been
truncated for the XFS case during parsing.

I believe it's a better idea to get this information directly out of
the state dictionary, which reflects the actual (post
configuration-munging) configuration being used.

Because we're getting the values from the state, we need to move the
exports after the "dib-block-device create" call.  This is OK, because
the values are intended for the bootloader elements which run after
this.  We move the SuSE mkinitrd into the finalise.d stage, from
post-install.d (where is should actually be in the correct file-system
anyway).

The mount/mkfs unit-test is updated to ensure the values are in the
state correctly.

Change-Id: I41dce6e25766562db4366021309b8c2b74a8ab80
Closes-Bug: 1742170
'}, {'created': '2018-01-29 04:11:16.000000000', 'message': 'Set default label for XFS disks

As described, we want to set the default label for XFS disks to the
shorter value.

For example, you hit this when setting the old FS_TYPE environment
variable to 'xfs' (which sets the "root-fs-type" parameter, which gets
passed through to 'type'; but does not set a default label).

Change-Id: I41dce6e25766562db4366021309b8c2b74a8ab80
Closes-Bug: 1742170
'}]
commit_message:
Set default label for XFS disks

As described, we want to set the default label for XFS disks to the
shorter value.

For example, you hit this when setting the old FS_TYPE environment
variable to 'xfs' (which sets the "root-fs-type" parameter, which gets
passed through to 'type'; but does not set a default label).

Change-Id: I41dce6e25766562db4366021309b8c2b74a8ab80
Closes-Bug: 1742170

subject: tempurl: Make the digest algorithm configurable
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2622, 'name': 'Samuel Merritt', 'email': 'sam@swiftstack.com', 'username': 'torgomatic'}, {'_account_id': 6968, 'name': 'Christian Schwede', 'email': 'cschwede@redhat.com', 'username': 'cschwede'}, {'_account_id': 7233, 'name': 'Matthew Oliver', 'email': 'matt@oliver.net.au', 'username': 'mattoliverau'}, {'_account_id': 13052, 'name': 'SwiftStack Cluster CI', 'email': 'openstack-ci@swiftstack.com', 'username': 'swiftstack-cluster-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 15343, 'name': 'Tim Burke', 'email': 'tburke@nvidia.com', 'username': 'tburke'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2017-12-05 21:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2017-12-28 04:20:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2017-12-28 19:12:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-05 19:18:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I think it'd be nice to have the algorithm as part of the query parameter, so instead of abc123def456, make it more like sha256:abc123def456. That'd cut down on the number of digests we have to compute in the tempurl middleware.

With this exact set of available hash functions, we can determine it by length, but if we add another hash function whose output size is the same as one of our existing ones, then we're stuck computing multiple HMACs no matter what we do."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-10 19:12:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I think it'd be nice to have the algorithm as part of the query parameter, so instead of abc123def456, make it more like sha256:abc123def456

Yeah, I thought about that (actually, almost *exactly* that -- I was also thinking of switching to base64 since a hex SHA-512 gets pretty long), but didn't want to be needlessly different from what cloud files seems to be doing -- see https://github.com/inflatador/ptemper/blob/master/ptemper.py#L186-L187 which got linked to on the bug report.

I'll play around with it, see what I come up with... I might also rethink how to approach func testing -- it seems unnecessary to have full copies of all tests that just switch between

- <hex-encoded sha1>
- <hex-encoded sha256>
- sha1:<base64-encoded sha1>
- sha256:<base64-encoded sha256>
- sha512:<base64-encoded sha512>
- whirlpool:<base64-encoded whirlpool>
- blake2b:<base64-encoded blake2b>
- ...whatever else we may end up adding in the future..."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-23 21:38:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-29 21:25:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-01-30 03:38:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Awesome work Tim!

Missing param in doc string and maybe add a test cap. Though might be bordering on a NIT.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-31 02:19:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-31 02:21:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-01-31 02:36:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

yeah, I don't want to engineer a flaky test.. although I also don't want to have a test that could potentially never end. Is a fail better then an infinite loop.

Anyway, you've gone through and done the maths.. I also ran the thing all night and the highest number of iterations I got was 10. And honestly 10 iterations is nothing and that's after thousands of runs. So I'm not too worried about it looping too long now. It'll only be a problem if urlsafe_b64 decided to not use either '_' or '-' :P

Sorry for my pedantic-iness :)"}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2018-01-31 09:14:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Great work Tim! Can't wait to see this merged. Didn't had a chance to run tests yet, so only +1 for now. Will try to run some tests later."}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2018-01-31 09:38:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Well, did a few tests on my machine and it works as expected. Let's merge this!"}]

"}, {'created': '2018-01-23 21:38:01.000000000', 'message': 'tempurl: Make the digest algorithm configurable

... and add support for SHA-256 and SHA-512 by default. This allows us
to start moving toward replacing SHA-1-based signatures. We've known
this would eventually be necessary for a while [1], and earlier this
year we've seen SHA-1 collisions [2].

Additionally, allow signatures to be base64-encoded, provided they start
with a digest name followed by a colon. Trailing padding is optional for
base64-encoded signatures, and both normal and "url-safe" modes are
supported. For example, all of the following SHA-1 signatures are
equivalent:

   da39a3ee5e6b4b0d3255bfef95601890afd80709
   sha1:2jmj7l5rSw0yVb/vlWAYkK/YBwk=
   sha1:2jmj7l5rSw0yVb/vlWAYkK/YBwk
   sha1:2jmj7l5rSw0yVb_vlWAYkK_YBwk=
   sha1:2jmj7l5rSw0yVb_vlWAYkK_YBwk

This was done for two reasons:

   1. A hex-encoded SHA-512 is rather lengthy at 128 characters.
   2. This will allow us to more-easily add support for different
      digests with the same bit length in the future.

Base64-encoding is required for SHA-512 signatures; hex-encoding is
supported for SHA-256 signatures so we aren't needlessly breaking from
what Rackspace is doing.

[1] https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2012/10/when_will_we_se.html
[2] https://security.googleblog.com/2017/02/announcing-first-sha1-collision.html

Change-Id: Ia9dd1a91cc3c9c946f5f029cdefc9e66bcf01046
Related-Bug: #1733634

to start moving toward replacing SHA-1-based signatures. We've known
this would eventually be necessary for a while [1], and earlier this
year we've seen SHA-1 collisions [2].

Additionally, allow signatures to be base64-encoded, provided they start
with a digest name followed by a colon. Trailing padding is optional for
base64-encoded signatures, and both normal and "url-safe" modes are
supported. For example, all of the following SHA-1 signatures are

   da39a3ee5e6b4b0d3255bfef95601890afd80709

   sha1:2jmj7l5rSw0yVb_vlWAYkK_YBwk

supported for SHA-256 signatures so we aren't needlessly breaking from

[1] https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2012/10/when_will_we_se.html

commit_message:
tempurl: Make the digest algorithm configurable

... and add support for SHA-256 and SHA-512 by default. This allows us
to start moving toward replacing SHA-1-based signatures. We've known
this would eventually be necessary for a while [1], and earlier this
year we've seen SHA-1 collisions [2].

Additionally, allow signatures to be base64-encoded, provided they start
with a digest name followed by a colon. Trailing padding is optional for
base64-encoded signatures, and both normal and "url-safe" modes are
supported. For example, all of the following SHA-1 signatures are
equivalent:

   da39a3ee5e6b4b0d3255bfef95601890afd80709
   sha1:2jmj7l5rSw0yVb/vlWAYkK/YBwk=
   sha1:2jmj7l5rSw0yVb/vlWAYkK/YBwk
   sha1:2jmj7l5rSw0yVb_vlWAYkK_YBwk=
   sha1:2jmj7l5rSw0yVb_vlWAYkK_YBwk

(Note that "normal" base64 encodings will require that you url encode
all "+" characters as "%2B" so they aren't misinterpretted as spaces.)

This was done for two reasons:

   1. A hex-encoded SHA-512 is rather lengthy at 128 characters -- 88
      isn't *that* much better, but it's something.
   2. This will allow us to more-easily add support for different
      digests with the same bit length in the future.

Base64-encoding is required for SHA-512 signatures; hex-encoding is
supported for SHA-256 signatures so we aren't needlessly breaking from
what Rackspace is doing.

[1] https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2012/10/when_will_we_se.html
[2] https://security.googleblog.com/2017/02/announcing-first-sha1-collision.html

Change-Id: Ia9dd1a91cc3c9c946f5f029cdefc9e66bcf01046
Related-Bug: #1733634

I can see a trunk from 'demo' project in the admin trunk panel, but there is no subport is shown in "Edit Trunk" form.

(2) "Create Trunk" in the admin trunk panel does not allow to create a trunk for other projects, so there seems no value of having "Create Trunk" button in the admin panel. commit_message:
Trunks panel: admin panel

Enable admin panel for trunks. For the admin panel the delete action and
the readonly operations are enabled (table view and details view).

Change-Id: Icfc01612cc60798e4b0ff7379a9c8b83d3f1d60b
Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-02 13:29:40.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Handle user-provided TLS certificate/key for the undercloud

instack-undercloud has support for using a user-provided certificate and
key. This is done through the undercloud_service_certificate
configuration option. This commit adds support for the same
functionality for the containerized undercloud.

It relies on pyca/cryptography, so I added it to the requirements.txt
file. And what it does is that it will read the PEM file and add the
parameter_defaults that are needed to enable TLS.

Change-Id: I26dbde57131f6328d0c5e400dcdfdf62cdd43a41

commit_message:
Handle user-provided TLS certificate/key for the undercloud

instack-undercloud has support for using a user-provided certificate and
key. This is done through the undercloud_service_certificate
configuration option. This commit adds support for the same
functionality for the containerized undercloud.

It relies on pyca/cryptography, so I added it to the requirements.txt
file. And what it does is that it will read the PEM file and add the
parameter_defaults that are needed to enable TLS.

Change-Id: I26dbde57131f6328d0c5e400dcdfdf62cdd43a41

commit_message:
Allowing Non-IP Traffic in L2 and L3 domains

Non-IP traffic is allowed in L2 and L3 Domains
The default_allow_non_ip setting determines if non-ip traffic is
allowed in Nuage specific L2 and L3 domains.

(cherry picked from commit 99edfb6c993cc5072d966c6851f73659ecd1e724)

Change-Id: I8fb0f86c8d8ae19700cf5803fea9eb7aaa73040a

commit_message:
Allowing Non-IP Traffic in L2 and L3 domains

Non-IP traffic is allowed in L2 and L3 Domains
The default_allow_non_ip setting determines if non-ip traffic is
allowed in Nuage specific L2 and L3 domains.

(cherry picked from commit 99edfb6c993cc5072d966c6851f73659ecd1e724)

Change-Id: I8fb0f86c8d8ae19700cf5803fea9eb7aaa73040a

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

subject: Support all_projects for cluster listing
messages:
[{'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2018-01-17 02:40:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2018-01-17 03:06:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2018-01-17 03:07:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2018-01-29 13:55:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(.venv) [centos@devstack python-magnumclient]$ openstack  coe cluster list --all-projects
list() got an unexpected keyword argument 'all_projects

check magnumclient/v1/baseunit.py"}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2018-02-01 02:25:24.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

After discussed with Spyros, we had decided to let admin user list all clusters without the extra 'all_projects' parameters, just like Heat, Glance etc. I will push another following patch to add a new parameter 'project_id' so that admin user can list clusters for a particular project."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-17 02:40:36.000000000', 'message': "Support all_projects for cluster listing

Add a new URL parameter 'all_tenants' for clusters listing API so
that admin user can list all clusters across tenants.

Change-Id: I1e786d3a1fbe064fc420a06a27fe22a33088efcc
Related-Bug: #1740982
"}, {'created': '2018-01-17 03:06:32.000000000', 'message': "Support all_projects for cluster listing

Add a new URL parameter 'all_tenants' for clusters listing API so
that admin user can list all clusters across tenants.

Change-Id: I1e786d3a1fbe064fc420a06a27fe22a33088efcc
Related-Bug: #1740982
"}]
commit_message:
Support all_projects for cluster listing

Add a new URL parameter 'all_tenants' for clusters listing API so
that admin user can list all clusters across tenants.

Change-Id: I1e786d3a1fbe064fc420a06a27fe22a33088efcc
Related-Bug: #1740982

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I0facc44637afd9b06e508f1d621f9280c1860458

commit_message:
add custom hostname_map to node config

In order to support custom hostname maps we
should run with a custom name in CI.

Depends-On: I1d6158a3ca26a36f09781184101df16ef7feda2a
Related-Bug: #1741569
Change-Id: I0f8c0c21273f033f62a66b3ec4de0f3f73883663

commit_message:
add the code required for hostname_map names

Based on information in the node configurations files
Create a custom parameter file for tripleo's hostname_map
feature.
Example: https://github.com/openstack-infra/tripleo-ci/blob/master/test-environments/hostname-map.yaml

Closes-Bug: #1741569
Change-Id: I1d6158a3ca26a36f09781184101df16ef7feda2a

commit_message:
Add more directories to collect

This patch adds /var/lib/kolla/config_files to collected logs to help
developers to debug Pike and newer versions of TripleO. /var/lib was sorted
alphanumerically for readability reasons.

Change-Id: I58b1d89b5801f60bc04ad116d91ce38a3476291b

commit_message:
Add more directories to collect

This patch adds /var/lib/kolla/config_files to collected logs to help
developers to debug Pike and newer versions of TripleO. /var/lib was sorted
alphanumerically for readability reasons.

Change-Id: I29f55d0717d0980d18cb7e6ee2941b376a97fac4

[{'created': '2018-01-04 23:33:26.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Add network policy

endpoints outlined in the values.yaml file.

commit_message:
Add egress network policy

This patch set adds network policy for egress for OpenStack
components charts. The ports and pod selectors are dynamically
generated based on the endpoints outlined in values.yaml.

Change-Id: I748a905c8e75c67000673145000eaf0b256a8697
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>

I'm very happy to see this change lshw looks much more usable than dmidecode. My concern for leaving dmidecode as a default dependency for tinyipa is to do with the size of the image, tinyipa is deliberately supposed to be as tiny as possible, over the last two cycles its grown about 3mb, from 38mb to 41mb adding lshw may make it grow even more.

We output the size of the image in the logs after build each time to make we can check, however there is an issue preventing us getting a result right now.

You need to add two lines like:

https://github.com/openstack/ironic-python-agent/blob/master/imagebuild/tinyipa/finalise-tinyipa.sh#L77

and 

https://github.com/openstack/ironic-python-agent/blob/master/imagebuild/tinyipa/finalise-tinyipa.sh#L119

to actually have your built package included in the final image, once that occurs we can see the final image size."}, {'account_id': 11929, 'date': '2017-12-20 14:50:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 11929, 'date': '2017-12-20 14:54:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Thanks Sam! Didn't realize there were more steps for including the build into the image. Added the lines you pointed out.

Are there any other uses for tinyipa other than the jobs here? If so, then I think tinyipa is only used with the GenericHardwareManager. Then we could definitely remove dmidecode from the deps list."}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2017-12-20 16:32:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

2017-12-20 15:38:11.045 | Produced files:
2017-12-20 15:38:11.047 | + ./finalise-tinyipa.sh:main:216           :   du -h tinyipa.gz tinyipa.tar.gz tinyipa.vmlinuz
2017-12-20 15:38:11.053 | 52M	tinyipa.gz
2017-12-20 15:38:11.053 | 55M	tinyipa.tar.gz
2017-12-20 15:38:11.053 | 3.7M	tinyipa.vmlinuz

Seems like lshw is adding 11mb on top of the previous 41mb size.'}, {'account_id': 11929, 'date': '2017-12-20 17:50:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Did a local build and it seems that a big contributor to the size are the id map files [0][1] used by lshw. They take up about 4.5 MB altogether. While we can't get around including them, I am not properly cleaning up after the build. I'm pretty sure that I'm leaving the source files behind, meaning that unused duplicates of these map files are left behind.

TL;DR, can probably shave off about 5 MB.

[0] https://github.com/lyonel/lshw/blob/master/src/pci.ids 1.01 MB
[2] https://github.com/lyonel/lshw/blob/master/src/oui.txt 3.28 MB"}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2017-12-20 17:53:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

The build and the final image 

 > Did a local build and it seems that a big contributor to the size
 > are the id map files [0][1] used by lshw. They take up about 4.5 MB
 > altogether. While we can't get around including them, I am not
 > properly cleaning up after the build. I'm pretty sure that I'm
 > leaving the source files behind, meaning that unused duplicates of
 > these map files are left behind.
 > 
 > TL;DR, can probably shave off about 5 MB.
 > 
 > [0] https://github.com/lyonel/lshw/blob/master/src/pci.ids 1.01 MB
 > [2] https://github.com/lyonel/lshw/blob/master/src/oui.txt 3.28 MB

The build and the final image actually occur in two separate chroots to avoid leaving behind build artifacts like this, so I don't think they've been included."}, {'account_id': 11929, 'date': '2017-12-22 17:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 11929, 'date': '2017-12-22 17:18:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Hey Sam,

I looked into the previous local build I did and found a /src/ directory which had the lshw sources (and duplicate map files).

I followed tgt's example and updated build-tinyipa.sh to compile lshw into a separate directory. Ran it locally and it seemed to reduce the size from 52 MB to 44 MB.

The /src/ directory no longer shows up on my local build. Let's see if it works in CI."}, {'account_id': 11929, 'date': '2017-12-23 13:46:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

My devstack logs show the process reaching build-tinyipa.sh and then nothing after [1]. Not sure what could be causing all of this but it seems to only happen after applying the patch. I've tried reproduce.sh with IPA's current master and the job succeeds.

Would appreciate any advice on how to proceed.

@dtantsur - This failure seems to be intermittent. It was happening to some of the succeeding jobs a few rechecks ago. I am unclear what's causing it. We're running the same make command, yet in some cases it hits the docbook2man dependency while in other cases it doesn't.

Two approaches to fixing this are
1) Include docbook2man as a dependency to the job. The problem I have with this is how large the docbook-utils package is. On my personal ubuntu instance, installing it took about 10 minutes and 720 MiB of space...

2) alter the make command to not build the man pages. This is preferable to me as we don't use the man pages to begin with but it does raise a slight problem. The make recipe for lshw uses a var called DATAFILES [0]. If we were to do a "make core" we would need to iterate the filenames from this var inline. If DATAFILES changes, we'd need to alter the make command to reflect this. I don't think this that big of a deal because we're frozen to a version of lshw. If ever the version of lshw changes, it would be reviewed. I think a comment explaining that DATAFILES needs to be checked would suffice.

Let me know what you think. Thanks!

[0] https://github.com/lyonel/lshw/blob/B.02.18/src/Makefile#L42'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-01-16 01:51:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> @dtantsur - This failure seems to be intermittent. It was happening
 > to some of the succeeding jobs a few rechecks ago. I am unclear
 > what's causing it. We're running the same make command, yet in some

 > doesn't.

 > 720 MiB of space...
 > 
 > 2) alter the make command to not build the man pages. This is

 > does raise a slight problem. The make recipe for lshw uses a var

 > to iterate the filenames from this var inline. If DATAFILES
 > changes, we'd need to alter the make command to reflect this. I
 > don't think this that big of a deal because we're frozen to a
 > version of lshw. If ever the version of lshw changes, it would be
 > reviewed. I think a comment explaining that DATAFILES needs to be
 > checked would suffice.
 > 
 > Let me know what you think. Thanks!
 > 
 > [0] https://github.com/lyonel/lshw/blob/B.02.18/src/Makefile#L42

A 3rd option would be to do:

 $CHROOT_CMD /bin/sh -c "cd /tmp/lshw && touch lshw.1 && make && make install DESTDIR=/tmp/lshw-installed"

That should "trick" make into thinking that it's already built the docs and never run docbook2man.  It's not like the manpage is helpful or used.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-01-16 11:13:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

And the 4th option is to provide a fake docbook2man executable :) Anyway, I like Tony's idea, maybe implement it? Just please leave a comment why we're doing that."}, {'account_id': 11929, 'date': '2018-01-16 12:51:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 11929, 'date': '2018-01-16 12:52:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

commit_message:
Use lshw in place of dmidecode for the default hardware manager

Currently the generic hardware manager uses dmidecode to get the
total physical memory and system details. This patch switches the
generic hardware manager to use lshw, as it is capable of reading
more than DMI [0]. This enables systems that do not support DMI
to use the generic hardware manager, such as IBM Power systems.

[0] https://github.com/lyonel/lshw/blob/master/README.md

Closes-Bug: #1715790
Change-Id: Ie370331df6bb5ef131c5cb60f458877e2a7ad71a
Depends-On: Idaf05b8efce28cd0cbf339cf693db4f55a693d9b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-17 19:43:19.000000000', 'message': 'future-proof invocation of apidoc

Newer versions of Sphinx have moved the apidoc module into sphinx.ext
and the API is slightly different (the function expects sys.argv[1:]
instead of sys.argv[:]. So, figure out where we can import it from and
set a flag so we can invoke it properly. See this change in sphinx for
details:
https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/87630c8ae8bff8c0e23187676e6343d8903003a6

Change-Id: I8235968f8a474c9e6088d935d0868570b2917c07

commit_message:
future-proof invocation of apidoc

Newer versions of Sphinx have moved the apidoc module into sphinx.ext
and the API is slightly different (the function expects sys.argv[1:]
instead of sys.argv[:]. So, figure out where we can import it from and
set a flag so we can invoke it properly. See this change in sphinx for
details:
https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/87630c8ae8bff8c0e23187676e6343d8903003a6

Change-Id: I8235968f8a474c9e6088d935d0868570b2917c07
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

'}]
commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I9661cb8f1aeec62d27e2e3746a2080b437a305d3

commit_message:
Add missing capabilities

The updates the powervm driver capabilities to include all capabilites
from nova [1].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/5251f18d8/nova/virt/driver.py#L124-L134

subject: Security group quota error handling
messages:
[{'account_id': 17505, 'date': '2018-01-31 07:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch stable/pike.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-31 08:25:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Ocata is the second phase of stable branches [1]. Only critical bugfixes and security patches are acceptable. I don't think it belongs to the category.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#support-phases"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-31 18:38:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Consider the situation after reading the discussion in the dev list on LTS, I reevaluated the impact of this backport. I am okay to accept this because it makes nothing worse and will reduce user-support efforts by operators.

On the other hand, I hope an update of the stable branch policy (with some note?).'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-31 18:38:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The topic name is confusing'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-31 18:39:07.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bug/1699724-stable/pike-stable/ocata to bug/1699724-stable/ocata'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-01-31 20:52:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Regarding the stable policy docs, there is a note right after the support phases table saying 'it depends':"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-01-31 20:52:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Regarding the stable policy docs, there is a note right after the support phases table saying, essentially, 'it depends':

https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#support-phases

"It’s nevertheless allowed to backport fixes for other bugs if their safety can be easily proved. For example, documentation fixes, debug log message typo corrections, test only changes, patches that enhance test coverage, configuration file content fixes can apply to all supported branches. For those types of backports, stable maintainers will decide on case by case basis."

Furthermore there is the "Appropriate fixes" section:

https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#appropriate-fixes

That also goes into detail about risk vs reward here.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-01-31 21:12:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Clean cherry pick from master (queens), the backport in stable/pike is approved, the neutronclient exception has been around since 2.3.5 (4 years ago) so this looks OK to me.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-31 07:45:00.000000000', 'message': 'Security group quota error handling

When adding a new rule to a secruity group that would exceede the
quota, the error message displays a quota error, rather than rule
already exists error. It does this my first checking for an
"OverQuotaClient" error, then if that except doesn't trigger it
checks for any other conflict

Change-Id: I8eaa0f00b25c8c3b75fef2bf46979f1f248c6896
Closes-Bug: #1699724
(cherry picked from commit 3929a8b7cd893f0b4c0ff6c20d5d1fd9077b4dd2)
'}]
commit_message:
Security group quota error handling

When adding a new rule to a secruity group that would exceede the
quota, the error message displays a quota error, rather than rule
already exists error. It does this my first checking for an
"OverQuotaClient" error, then if that except doesn't trigger it
checks for any other conflict

Change-Id: I8eaa0f00b25c8c3b75fef2bf46979f1f248c6896
Closes-Bug: #1699724
(cherry picked from commit 3929a8b7cd893f0b4c0ff6c20d5d1fd9077b4dd2)

commit_message:
Let enforcer.py work under both py2 and py3

I guess the gate uses py3, but some of the post jobs still use py2?
Whatever, it's easy enough to support both.

See http://logs.openstack.org/f9/f9b96861577e26f0540158e00706e2505213f4bf/post/publish-openstack-sphinx-docs/58260e1/ara/result/8a18f0c0-d4b0-4cef-9d31-4cf79f3b4999/
for an example failure.

Change-Id: I37e507d37d4a41f5c55f2314bc074556f6262b50

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-31 20:03:04.000000000', 'message': 'update new-release to support forced procedural tags

At the end of the queens cycle we had several libraries that had no
releases at all. In order to create the stable/queens branches we
wanted to go back to the point where the stable/pike branch had been
created and tag again, raising the minor version number. This patch
updates the new-release command to compute those values automatically
when an argument of "procedural" is given.

It also extends the schema for the deliverable file to support a
"comment" field. We can't use regular source comments because there is
no way to tell the formatter to emit them.

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
update new-release to support forced procedural tags

At the end of the queens cycle we had several libraries that had no
releases at all. In order to create the stable/queens branches we
wanted to go back to the point where the stable/pike branch had been
created and tag again, raising the minor version number. This patch
updates the new-release command to compute those values automatically
when an argument of "procedural" is given.

It also extends the schema for the deliverable file to support a
"comment" field. We can't use regular source comments because there is
no way to tell the formatter to emit them.

Change-Id: I53850f55e4bae54e82b715888b33e8ea87e264d5
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Submit select roles

* Change FormErrorList to render standard alert
* Add SelectRolesForm validation
* Add actions for selecting roles and handling zaqar message

Implements: blueprint tripleo-ui-select-roles
Depends-On: I42d66da37dcb07c1be112623d89769377bb23284
Change-Id: I1305b5cb1522ca18f03c4c5113b822a86aff5d97

commit_message:
Update dependencies part II

Dependency changes:
* updated formsy-react [MIT] https://github.com/formsy/formsy-react
* updated normalizr [MIT]https://github.com/paularmstrong/normalizr
* updated patternfly-react [MIT] https://github.com/patternfly/patternfly-react
* updated prop-types [MIT] https://github.com/reactjs/prop-types
* updated react [MIT] https://github.com/facebook/react
* updated react-dom [MIT] https://github.com/facebook/react
* updated redux-form [MIT] https://github.com/erikras/redux-form
* updated react-test-renderer [MIT] https://github.com/facebook/react
* updated react-bootstrap [MIT] https://github.com/react-bootstrap/react-bootstrap
* updated redux-form-validators [MIT] https://github.com/gtournie/redux-form-validators
* removed babel-preset-es2015

Fixes:
* Update Normalizr schemes to use new API
* Formsy.HOC -> withFormsy
* Formsy.Form -> Formsy, addValidationRule
* Fix failing tests
* Fix redux-form infinite loop in ToolbarFiltersForm
* Fix RegisterNodesDialog infinite loop when adding node
* Fix nodepicker input infinite loop
* Fix Icons in ListView to use lates patternfly-react

Partial-Bug: 1743722
Change-Id: I0a4668bd49c499c1542893995497e529c8e01535

commit_message:
Impose limits on application credentials

In order to protect against possible abuse or bloat, add a config option
to set a limit on the number of application credentials a user may have.

bp application-credentials

Change-Id: Ieab33c3265fa0c0b1b1c6d586e5ea8a9a39edfb1

subject: use a semaphore to protect static-publish job output

[{'created': '2018-01-31 21:40:50.000000000', 'message': 'use a semaphore to protect static-publish job output

commit_message:
use a semaphore to protect static-publish job output

We only want one static-publish job running at any given time for any
given project repo, so set up a semaphore to ensure that is the case.

Change-Id: Ib0529d103a2b657c965dbb3b778fa2e495d2da2a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add instack-undercloud subpackages from delorean-current

https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/11637/ has created a new
package instack-undercloud-container. This must be installed
from delorean-current as instack-undercloud when deploying in
TripleO CI.

Change-Id: Ie0aa8240f28f2d4f87e19041db2145fedf5fe496

subject: Fixes websocket to use TLS when ODL NB is TLS

Basically this should be fixed and unit test is needed.
Do you have any reason to hold this patch as WIP?'}, {'account_id': 17280, 'date': '2018-01-17 20:43:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Basically this should be fixed and unit test is needed.
 > Do you have any reason to hold this patch as WIP?

I was just marking it as WIP while I tested it and added releasenote/unit test.  I can confirm the websocket connection comes up correctly with this fix.  Will create a follow up patch set.'}, {'account_id': 333, 'date': '2018-01-18 01:32:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for reply. I wanted to know this is for queens or later.
The code freeze for queens is approaching.'}, {'account_id': 17280, 'date': '2018-01-18 16:54:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Thanks for reply. I wanted to know this is for queens or later.
 > The code freeze for queens is approaching.

Yeah this fix is really a check to ensure what networking-odl uses to connect is correct.  Right now the URL provided by ODL is wrong.  There is also a fix in ODL to correct it:
https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/67283/

But it makes networking-odl more resilient to have this check in case this happens again.  Technically because it should be fixed in ODL I don't know that we *need* it in queens, but it is a small change and should be able to make it by MS3.  Will add a unit test and upload new patch set momentarily."}, {'account_id': 17280, 'date': '2018-01-18 20:24:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2018-01-23 14:45:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

nice catch.

this issue and forces the URI to be TLS secured when the ML2 ODL URL is
set to use TLS.

commit_message:
Fixes websocket to use TLS when ODL NB is TLS

Currently when websocket is registered with ODL REST, the returned
websocket URI is given without TLS prefix (wss:).  This patch checks for
this issue and forces the URI to be TLS secured when the ML2 ODL URL is
set to use TLS.

Change-Id: Ifabfe13a593cfd415afa78018332190ef7dbb507
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Enable application_credential auth by default

There's no reason users shouldn't be able to use application credentials
out of the box. Make application_credential one of the default enabled
auth methods.

bp application-credentials

Change-Id: Ib8a02ef7b8f0efadfe902d7e517ac702f72fff13

commit_message:
Add application credential auth plugin

Add an auth plugin for application credentials and update the common
auth utilities to understand an auth method of 'application_credential'
and validate and scope accordingly.

By default, application credentials should not be allowed to be used for
creating other application credentials or trusts. If a user creates an
application credential with flag `allow_application_credential_creation`
then that application should be allowed to be used for creating and
deleting other application credentials and trusts. Ensure a flag is set
in the token if this property is set to allow this behavior.

bp application-credentials

Change-Id: I15a03e79128a11314d06751b94343f22d533243a

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I82c3467ab72d593e155cb61f727235b7f4468195

commit_message:
Revert "Remove the overcloudrc.v3 file"

This reverts commit 977bc6f1b864c2cee9a92c9de1acee109d5e0195.

The original change is backwards incompatible since it removes the
overcloudrc v3 file without any deprecation.

Related-Bug: #1733640
Change-Id: I6b62e014312f7502a693f2990556d58696b1df11

[{'created': '2018-01-31 00:50:32.000000000', 'message': "Make container image upload more resilient

This change implements a retry loop for the image push, just like the
existing one for pull. This will be necessary for some non-undercloud
registries which might periodically fail on some pushes.

This change also determines the upload worker count to be half of the
CPU count, with a minimum of two. This is to make CI more resilient on
smaller (6 core) flavors. A docker pull causes high CPU load in
dockerd, as the download of each layer is spread across dockerd's
workers.

Change-Id: Ia30658e3283d4b69d2bd8b0dddd375e1918169d3
Closes-Bug: #1746305
"}, {'created': '2018-01-31 03:52:16.000000000', 'message': "Make container image upload more resilient

existing one for pull. This will be necessary for some non-undercloud
registries which might periodically fail on some pushes.

This change also determines the upload worker count to be half of the
CPU count, with a minimum of two. This is to make CI more resilient on
smaller (6 core) flavors. A docker pull causes high CPU load in

Change-Id: Ia30658e3283d4b69d2bd8b0dddd375e1918169d3
Closes-Bug: #1746305
